They only have to act as if they recognize the dynamics. The strategy of appearing to be tougher than you truly are can survive as a crude decision rule, based on past experiences of the judges.

  • 107 Another positive effect of the make-it-look-like-a-struggle strategy is in limiting “reputational spillover effects.” The revelation of bad news about one company may cause stakeholders to lose trust in the whole industry or market. These cascading dynamics, caused by biases such as availability heuristics, are bad for the economy as a whole. And to the extent that Delaware manages to convey a message of keeping corporate America in check, it can restore some of the trust and avoid unnecessary punishing of good companies. We come back to this point in the Conclusion.

  • 108 To emphasize: I do not claim that Delaware judges act with Machiavellian intentions to slow down Washington (or reputational markets) by making it look like a struggle. It is certainly possible that Delaware judges employ scolding because they believe that the alternative - intervening and imposing legal sanctions - is too costly.

4

Public Enforcement

The SEC 's Settlement Practices

4.1 Introduction

Public enforcement affects reputations too. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) enforcement actions, in particular, play a key role in shaping the behavior of publicly traded companies. Much like with private litigation, SEC enforcement shapes behavior not just through imposing fines but also through producing information. This chapter examines how effective SEC enforcement practices are in generating valuable information and facilitating reputational sanctioning. Switching our focus from Delaware litigation to SEC investigations enriches our understanding of the law-and-reputation theory and illustrates its broad applicability. Most notably, we learn how regulatory enforcement actions generate different reputational dynamics than private litigation.

Our starting point is the heated national debate that ensued at the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, over the SEC settlement practices. That debate focused on whether the SEC settles for large enough awards (it does). This chapter shifts focus and examines whether SEC settlements produce enough valuable information to facilitate market deterrence (they do not).

Section 4.2 lays the background by describing the common practice of neither-admit-nor-deny settlements. Section 4.3 details the ways in which such SEC settlements underproduce information. Section 4.4 explains why the SEC has traditionally opted to underproduce information. Section 4.5 examines whether recent changes to SEC enforcement practices can solve the information-underproduction problem, and finds them wanting. Section 4.6 sketches alternative solutions to information underproduction, such as reevaluating the proper scope of judicial review of SEC actions. Section 4.7 concludes with big-picture observations on the information-production qualities of SEC enforcement actions relative to those of private securities litigation.

4.2 Neither-Admit-Nor-Deny Settlements: the Existing Debate

SEC enforcement actions historically followed a distinct pattern: the SEC learns about an alleged misconduct, investigates the matter, and then brings actions (files a complaint) only to simultaneously announce a pre-negotiated settlement with the defendants.1 The typical settlement contains a three-pronged obligation by the defendant company: paying a fine,2 agreeing to an injunction barring similar misconduct in the future, and agreeing not to deny the allegations. In return, the SEC terminates the action and allows the company not to admit the allegations. The agreement is then brought before a federal judge who signs it and turns it into a consent judgment (also known as a “consent decree”).3

This long-standing practice of neither-admit-nor-deny settlements went unchecked for many years, until Judge Rakoff of the Southern District of New York started raising questions vocally. In a sequence of three notable opinions -Bank of America,4 Vitesse,5 and Citigroup6 - Judge Rakoff decried the practice in general and refused to sign specific consent pacts. Other judges quickly followed suit, sparking a trend of increased scrutiny of SEC settlements.7 In no time, SEC settlement practices had become the center of national attention.8 A heated debate ensued over the effectiveness of SEC enforcement and the proper scope of judicial review.

Those who argued against current SEC settlement practices (and consequently were in favor of enhanced judicial scrutiny) claimed that the SEC plays favorites with big-firm defendants, allowing them to get off with small fines and not admitting wrongdoing. The SEC and opponents of enhanced judicial scrutiny countered with two types of arguments.9 First, they claimed, there is nothing wrong with the amount of awards collected in settlements. When evaluating whether the collected amount makes sense, one needs to consider the alternative to settling: wasting limited resources on a costly litigation while risking not proving violations and collecting nothing. Second, the SEC claimed, SEC settlements contribute to sanctioning and deterrence not just through imposing fines but also through producing information. The SEC announces settlements with a press release that details the allegations, thus putting market players on notice about how the defendants behaved. And since defendants are barred from denying the allegations,— the SEC’s version goes uncontested and is considered reliable.

Given the theme of this book, we will focus on the second type of arguments - evaluating whether SEC settlements do indeed inform market participants about wrongdoing. I leave aside the first type of arguments not only because of scope but also because I think that there is no real reason to question the SEC’s official line.— The SEC has incentives to maximize the amounts it collects even without judicial scrutiny, because this is how the SEC’s monitors -in the press, Congress, or academia - measure its success.— Take the Citigroup case as an example. The absolute maximum that the SEC could have collected had it fought and won a trial is $320 million;— the amount that the SEC got in settlement was $285 million. The SEC did not leave money on the table with Citigroup. It rarely does.14 Moreover, federal judges are not well positioned to decide questions such as whether to settle and for how much: such decisions require not only factoring the particulars of the case at hand but also prioritizing the budgetary constraints and caseload pressures of the agency.15 On the other hand, we have plenty of reasons to question the SEC’s claim that its settlements provide useful information. They do not. The rest of this chapter explains why.

4.3 Identifying the Problem: How SEC Settlements Underproduce Information

The SEC’s argument about the informative value of settlements misses an important distinction between the quantity and quality of information. More information does not necessarily translate into a better information environment. The SEC is right to suggest that its settlements produce more information than private settlements - as is manifested in summarizing the allegations in press releases and making detailed complaints available. But the information that the SEC typically releases is not reputation-relevant. It does not help market players distinguish between good and bad actors. In order for SEC settlements to impact market players’ beliefs and facilitate better reputational sanctioning, they have to provide new facts or credible interpretations. The typical SEC settlement fails to do that,16 for several reasons.

First, putting the public on notice is helpful only if the public has not already noticed the wrongdoing. One influential study that examined how news on corporate fraud breaks, found that SEC actions break the news in only 7 percent of the cases.17 In general, when the wrongdoing is done on a large scale and by visible companies, the media usually covers it long before the SEC releases information.18 In the Bank of America settlement announcement, for example, every piece of information was stale.19 The informative value of putting the public on notice thus depends on the baseline. To generalize: the notice has an informative value in actions against small broker-dealers, where but for the SEC announcement the violation would not have been noticed. Conversely, notice by itself has little informative value in settlements of the Bank of America and Citigroup kind, where the public had already noticed that something wrong had happened, and the role of the SEC was to focus on explaining how exactly things went wrong: what specific control weaknesses led to the wrongdoing? Was it really just a low-level rogue employee or a more pervasive problem?

Second, the reputational impact of settlement announcements is further diluted by the SEC’s tendency to target whole industries.20 Announcing that company X allegedly engaged in wrongdoing does not really help market players if all company X’s competitors face similar allegations. Stakeholders cannot take their business elsewhere - cannot dispense reputational sanctions -unless the SEC provides details that distinguish between one alleged wrongdoing and another: which are attributed to technical errors and which reflect more deep-seated issues.21

Third, the SEC often lets defendants shape the content and timing of announcements. Most of the settlements are pre-negotiated,22 and the SEC lets big-firm defendants minimize the reputational impact in two ways. The simultaneous announcement of complaint and settlement limits the negative publicity exposure to only one event. And it allows defendants to put a “nothing to see here” spin on what could have been damning indications about their behavior. The bad news of allegations is comingled with the good news of “case closed.”

Aside from timing, the pre-negotiation also allows defendants to shape the public perception of the SEC’s allegations by affecting the language of SEC announcements. As part of the negotiations, defendants get to revise the regulator’s drafts.23 It is not just that defendants are not required to admit wrongdoing; they also get to dictate how the SEC’s version of what happened will be presented. The Citigroup case illustrates how the SEC’s public version is watered down compared to the SEC’s internal version. In Citigroup, the same misconduct (material statement) led to two complaints: one against the company, and one against an employee (Brian Stoker). Yet for some reason the language used to describe the misconduct was different. The complaint against the company emphasizes that no bad intentions were involved, while the Stoker complaint does indicate intentionality.— The complaint against Stoker mentions the gross revenues collected by Citigroup in the toxic transaction, while the complaint against Citigroup uses only the less damning net-profits figure. Both aspects - the degree of intentionality involved and harm done - are important determinants of reputational sanctions. The framing of the Citigroup complaint therefore limited the reputational damages to the company.

Finally, the SEC argues that settlement announcements are informative even without containing admissions, simply because defendants are barred from denying the allegations. But in reality the “no denial” requirement is not (and perhaps cannot be) enforced. The information contained in the SEC allegations is open to interpretation and disagreement, if only because companies find ways to implicitly contest the allegations.25 Indeed, SEC Commissioner Luis Aguilar himself decried the common practice of “the press release issued by a defendant after a settlement explaining how the conduct was really not that bad or that the regulator overreacted.”— Other current and former securities regulators agree that there is no such thing as a “no-spin zone”: defendants find various ways to bypass the requirement.27

The upshot is that SEC settlements with big companies underproduce relevant information. The next question is why. SEC investigations generate internally high-quality information on how things went wrong; so why does the SEC not publicly convey information in a comprehensible and thorough way? Why does the SEC leave information on the table in settlements? The following Section locates the roots of the information-underproduction problem in the reputational incentives of both parties to SEC settlements.

4.4 Explaining the Problem: Why the SEC Trades Information for Fines

Large publicly traded companies have incentives to pay slightly higher settlement awards as long as they can prevent unfavorable information about them from reaching the market. This is because negative information may generate reputational ramifications,— which are more risky for large companies than legal sanctions. Chapter 1 showed us that the typical reputational sanction attached to revealed misconduct dwarfs the equivalent legal sanction. Moreover, many types of legal sanctions are paid by insurance companies, while reputational damages are less easily insurable. Large companies therefore typically fear an uptick in reputational sanctions more than they fear an uptick in legal sanctions.

As for the SEC’s incentives, here the story gets more complicated. One could argue that the SEC decision makers’ incentives are aligned with the public interest, and so whenever the SEC blocks information from getting to the market it is only because the benefits from settling early and for larger amounts outweigh the informational benefits. From that perspective information underproduction is not really a problem but rather a welfare-enhancing tradeoff. But such an argument misses how the incentives of agents work in a multitasking environment. When agents make tradeoffs between multiple tasks they tend to overemphasize the tasks that are being closely monitored by principals.— The SEC’s constituencies - the general public and congressional overseers - evaluate the SEC mostly according to readily observable yardsticks such as the amount of fines collected or the number of cases brought.— The public and Congress have difficulties in observing and attributing the indirect benefits from information production to the SEC. The logic of incentives therefore suggests that the SEC will prioritize the number of cases brought and the amount of fines collected. Indeed, the SEC’s own communications reflect such emphasis;31 and former SEC staffers acknowledged that the SEC tilts the fines-information tradeoff against providing information and to the detriment of the public interest.—

The upshot is that even well-meaning SEC officials face reputational pressures to favor fines over information. Before we discuss how to mitigate these tendencies, let us first evaluate two recent changes that the SEC has implemented after its public battle with Judge Rakoff. The SEC has reportedly switched to requiring more admissions in settlements, and filing most of its settlements administratively instead of before federal courts. Could these changes improve information production? The next section examines.

  • 4.5 Recent Changes in SEC Practices Did Not Alleviate the Problem

4.5.1 More Admissions

On paper, the SEC already seems to be trending in the right direction. Under the leadership of Chairman Mary Jo White the SEC changed its settlement policy to require more admissions from certain defendants.— Immediately after, in September 2013, the SEC announced twenty-three neither-admit-nor-deny settlements with firms accused of short selling;— and two days later a settlement where JPMorgan not only paid $200 million but also admitted wrongdoing.— In real time, I opined that these two announcements suggest that the SEC has its priorities straight going forward, based on the type of violations and the companies involved. The alleged violation in short-selling cases does not require intent, and the firms involved are not household names. By contrast, when a giant like JPMorgan is charged with misstating financial results and lacking internal controls, it becomes essential that the public gets credible detailed information on how things went wrong.

However, in the years that have passed since, scholars who systematically examined the new admission policy found it wanting.— The SEC touts its new policy as a great success, claiming that the increased number of admissions translates into greater corporate accountability. But the recent empirical studies adopt a more skeptical view. They agree that there has been an uptick in admissions, but question whether it translates into an uptick in accountability. These studies go over the underlying settlements, and suggest that the admissions are largely nominal, and the admitters are mostly small fish. Importantly for our information-production perspective, the studies document how most admissions do not pertain to the state of mind or internal checks and balances of the offenders. In other words, the offenders admit to the “what happened” question (on which the market usually already has a good grasp), but do not admit to the “how it happened” question (on which the market could have used the help from SEC investigations).

In fact, there may be reason to suspect that the SEC’s need to score admissions results in a worse information environment. When the SEC negotiates with the misbehaving companies behind closed doors, admissions “confer a significant bargaining chip that companies can trade away in exchange for fewer incriminating disclosures.”—

4.5.2 Filing Administratively

An even more dramatic change in SEC practices came in the form of shifting to file settlements in administrative proceedings, rather than in federal courts.— Filings administratively comes with several benefits. But from our perspective here - information production - it makes things worse. An administrative filing means that SEC’s negotiations with defendants are approved internally, by a committee of SEC commissioners, without outside review.— The lack of third-party review means it is less likely that information will become publicly accessible (aside from the pre-negotiated SEC press release). Further, filing administratively allows the SEC to regularly open and close an enforcement action on the same day, which, we already saw, dilutes the reputational impact of what the SEC internally found out about the misbehavior.

Generally, it is not surprising that changes to SEC practices tend not to lead to better information production. The root problem is the one we discussed earlier: the SEC is not measured according to how it facilitates reputational deterrence, but rather according to observable yardsticks, such as concrete enforcement numbers. The first step toward fixing the information-underproduction problem is therefore raising awareness to it among the SEC overseers and its own staff. The next section sketches concrete implications for judicial review and regulatory agenda-setting.

  • 4.6 Solving the Problem

4.6.1 Changes to Judicial Scrutiny

Armed with a fresh perspective on SEC settlements, we can revisit the evergreen question of the proper scope of judicial review. As a starting point, we should switch from arguing “for or against” SEC settlements to concentrating on what type of SEC settlements we want. The solution to current problems with SEC settlements is not necessarily more litigation,40 but rather better-designed settlements and prioritizing of cases. SEC settlements can and should provide market players with more credible information on how exactly companies misbehaved.

For SEC settlements that are still filed in federal courts, judicial review can ideally nudge SEC enforcement in the direction of better information production. To be sure, judicial review is a very imperfect method for improving SEC settlements. Judges themselves are fallible and may interfere even when the SEC makes the right considerations.— My point here is not to advocate for more judicial scrutiny, but rather for better judicial scrutiny, with clear guidelines for its application.42 I offer two simple guidelines. First, judges should generally maintain deference to the SEC. Interference raises the costs of settlements and limits the range of mutually beneficial bargains between the regulator and the regulated entities. Second, the main trigger for judicial intervention in rare cases should be information production and not severity of fines. Judges should interfere whenever the settlement withholds quality information on a topic that is of wide interest to the market.43

To illustrate, consider how Judge RakofEs war against neither-admit-nor-deny settlements played out. In 2014, the Second Circuit Court of Appeals reached a decision in the Citigroup case, vacating Judge Rakoffs refusal to approve the settlement.44 Seen from the informational perspective developed here, the Court of Appeals’ decision sets a bad precedent: it focuses the permissible scope of judicial review on the procedural aspects of the consent decree, and explicitly limits the judge’s ability to demand more information on what and how things happened. When this judicial tendency to not interfere in information underproduction is coupled with the abovementioned regulator’s tendency to file settlements administratively (which limits the scope for judicial intervention to begin with), the likely result is weaker reputational deterrence.

4.6.2 Changes to Enforcement Policy

If the SEC wishes to optimize information production and facilitate reputational deterrence, it should reprioritize its enforcement cases. The SEC needs to concentrate resources on cases that produce big informational benefits (disputes with giant financial firms), even at the expense of amassing complaints and litigating against smaller firms or low-level employees.

To borrow an analogy from communication science: the SEC needs to shift to a “burglar alarm” mode of reporting. In the past decade communication scholars have been advocating a shift from the traditional “all the news that’s fit to print” mode of journalism to a burglar-alarm approach.— The idea is that nowadays, with the advancement of information technologies, citizens can easily access information on all issues. What citizens need is not more information but rather someone to sift the information for them: a reputable intermediary that will direct citizens’ scant attention to the few pieces of information that are more relevant and critical. The same can be said with regard to SEC settlements. Nowadays market players learn about financial misconduct from multiple sources. The SEC should therefore switch from merely putting us on notice that lots of bad things are happening to flagging the more problematic cases -providing detailed information on the most important cases and directing market players’ attention to instances where they greatly under or overstated problems.

A second proposal that could mitigate the information-underproduction problem involves changing the common practice of announcing the complaint and settlement together. We saw earlier that comingling the announcements limits the media follow-up and allows companies to put a “business as usual” spin on the allegations. A straightforward solution would be to disentangle the two announcements. The SEC should not file a settlement until, say, a week has passed since it announced the filing of a complaint. Think about it as a sort of “notice and comment” period:— the media and other intermediaries (analysts, institutional investors) would get to devote attention to, and weigh in on, the allegations. The company will have to address them. And the SEC overseers will have an opportunity to judge whether settling the case is in the public’s best interest.

4.7 Private Litigation vs. Public Enforcement: the Information-Production Perspective

Instead of concluding by summarizing the previous sections, let us synthesize what we have learned about the reputational effects of SEC enforcement by comparing them to the reputational effects of private litigation. Which mode of enforcement injects more valuable information to the market and facilitates better reputational deterrence?

On paper, it may seem that the SEC enforcement division possesses better tools and incentives than private litigants to produce credible information. The SEC enjoys broader investigative powers compared to the ones private litigants typically enjoy in a post-PSLRA world.47 And as for incentives, private litigants are incentivized to trade away information for money: it is not just that they settle too early and too often, but also that they settle too secretly. Almost every settlement comes with some form of a confidentiality clause.48 By contrast, the SEC can produce press releases that detail their investigations in a fairer way than plaintiffs’-lawyer-worded complaints or media briefs. All this has led a few scholars to suggest that we can do away with private securities litigation (e.g., by allowing companies to adopt mandatory arbitration provisions with class action waivers), and instead shift more resources to SEC enforcement and whistleblowing programs.49

Yet the SEC enforcement-produces-better-information-environment argument applies only in a limited sense: in a specific dispute, SEC enforcement may indeed be equally/more informative than private litigation. But as far as the big picture is concerned, the overall information that comes out of SEC enforcement actions as a whole cannot fully substitute for the overall information that comes out due to private litigation. Private enforcement produces information in ways and on types of misconduct on which the SEC consistently underproduces information.

For one, the SEC faces budgetary constraints. It does not have the ability to pursue all investigations of misconduct that private litigators have traditionally taken on.50 The limited resources mean that the SEC has to prioritize targets, and various empirical studies show that the SEC prioritizes in a distorted way. The SEC has historically favored going after small fish rather than big fish,— and provided laxer treatment for firms that are more politically connected.52 The plaintiffs’ bar, by contrast, pursues companies with much bigger market caps and without apparent political biases.53 Private litigation is therefore likely to pursue - and flush out information on - instances of corporate misconduct that public enforcement ignores.

To reiterate: when we question the SEC’s incentives, we do not need to assume a hardcore regulatory capture story. Publicly spirited SEC decision makers maximize what they are being measured upon. And they are being measured upon the total amount of fines it collects and the number of enforcement actions it opens. From our viewpoint, the problem is that in pursuing these numbers the SEC too often trades off information. It often lets the targets of its enforcement actions influence the language and timing of the enforcement action press release. It tends to target whole industries for minor offenses. Targeting whole industries does not affect reputations: the stakeholders of company X cannot punish the company for misbehaving if all company X’s competitors face similar allegations (they cannot take their business elsewhere).

Further, targeting companies for strict liability offenses allows the SEC to investigate and prosecute quickly, but produces little reputational value.54 Enforcement action for a strict liability offense would tell the market that something happened, but would not normally elaborate on how things happened. It would not produce internal company documents showing who knew what when.

Indeed, Choi and Pritchard provided evidence that private attorneys may be better at flushing out certain types of misconduct than the SEC.55 Their study found that the credibility of the defendant company’s disclosures takes a bigger hit following a standalone class action, than it does following a standalone SEC investigation. Institutional ownership and earnings responsiveness - both proxies for how the market perceives disclosure credibility - drop more for companies that were targeted by a class action than they do for companies that were targeted by the SEC.

To be sure, private litigants’ incentives to produce information are far from perfect. Our message here is not that private litigation is categorically better than SEC enforcement in information production. In line with Chapter 2, our message here is not to treat private litigation and SEC enforcement as a horserace, where we need to determine who the sole winner of information production is. We can acknowledge that both systems are flawed, and still recognize that the systems’ coexistence can make things better as long as each system’s flaws are imperfectly correlated with the other’s.56 For example, private litigants have incentives to get damning information out early in the process, to survive the motion to dismiss and leverage their claims into a hefty settlement. The SEC, by contrast, keeps any damning information it extracts confidential until after a settlement was reached.57 Chapter 8 comes back to this point, when discussing the mandatory arbitration revolution, which threatens to end shareholder litigation as we came to know it. In a world without private litigation, public enforcement cannot be counted on to carry the information-production load on its own.
