Corporate Philanthropy as Signaling and Co-optation

5.1 Introduction

Why do business companies donate to charity? Why do some companies donate more than others? The prevalent answers to these questions usually invoke reputation: companies donate in hope of securing good reputation among their stakeholders, or so the argument goes. Yet, the same problem we observed with the conventional wisdom on reputational sanctions appears here as well, with the conventional wisdom on reputational rewards: all too often legal scholars simply assume that donating to charity boosts a company’s reputation, without fully examining how reputational rewards work, or how the legal regime influences companies’ reputational incentives to donate.

This chapter argues that, contrary to common wisdom, corporate philanthropy is less about boosting a firm’s reputation for being nice, and more about boosting a firm’s reputation for being financially sound or having good products. The chapter also delineates the circumstances under which companies’ donations do not result in reputational rewards, but rather destroy value and become a corporate governance problem. Finally, the chapter examines how the existing legal regime - which in the United States is virtually a regulatory vacuum - hurts the ability of reputation markets to incentivize impactful corporate prosociality.

Our starting point is the undeniable prominence of the corporate social responsibility (CSR) movement. Companies nowadays increasingly invest resources in activities that do not directly benefit the bottom line or meet legal requirements. They move to greener production, become more employee-friendly, or donate to charitable causes. The ever-growing phenomenon of corporate prosociality impacts not just social and environmental causes, but also financial allocations. Indeed, over $12 trillion are currently invested in part based on corporate social performance.1

Yet despite its growing importance, corporate prosociality remains an elusive phenomenon. This is especially true in the corporate law literature where, instead of understanding the causes and consequences of prosocial profit sacrificing, commentators traditionally focus their attention on the endless normative debate over whether corporations should engage in non-maximizing activities.2 Even when the focus is shifted to understanding why companies behave prosocially, the discussion anachronistically alludes to the market forces driving corporate prosociality, without attempting to understand what affects those market forces.

Instead of grouping all CSR activities together, I focus on the subset of corporate philanthropy (CP).3 CP is defined as corporate donations to qualified (i.e., tax-exempt) charitable organizations.4 I focus, then, on behaviors that are more explicitly non-maximizing. I will not focus on behaviors like treating employees nicely, where the expenditures are on the immediate corporate realm (operational profit sacrificing), or on behaviors like cause-related marketing or corporate sponsorships of sports events, which are more akin to traditional advertising. By contrast, CP lacks expectations for an immediate, direct quid pro quo. When a New York-based investing bank donates $10 million to build a shelter home for the poor in Atlanta, the beneficiaries of the donation will likely not buy from, work for, or invest in the company. Focusing on CP allows us to resist “fighting the hypothetical,” that is, evading issues arising from profit sacrificing by assuming that the behavior is really profit maximizing in disguise.5

The first contribution of this chapter comes from revising the current “profit-enhancing approach,” which construes CP as buying goodwill for the company. We cannot simply assume that companies, by acting nicely, would boost their reputations. Instead, we should ask: reputation for what? To whom? And how does CP affect it - what do outsiders infer when they observe companies significantly increasing their prosocial expenditures?

The answer, I argue, lies in costly signaling. Explicit sacrifices of profits can serve as costly signals that build a firm’s reputation. They reliably convey messages about attributes that are important to shareholders, consumers, and employees, who are evaluating whether to invest in, buy products from, or work for those companies. For example, CP can serve as a costly signal that builds a firm’s reputation toward its investors. An increase in the level of donations could convey messages about financial strength to potential investors, who could infer that future free cash flows are perceived by insiders to be relatively high, that the company is now less financially constrained, or that the riskiness of future cash flows has decreased. Acknowledging the possibility that benefits arise from signaling also has legal implications: laws affect the flow and quality of information, as well as the choice of signals.

The second contribution comes from revisiting the “agency-costs approach,” which views CP as a managerial perk. Yet even if we assume that CP decisions are driven by managerial utility, it is unclear whether they are detrimental to shareholder value or merely a value-neutral diversion (i.e., a substitute for other managerial perks within a fixed level of appropriation). The more relevant question, I claim, is whether insiders can use their discretion over corporate donations to dilute the mechanisms that are supposed to cap managerial agency costs. CP can be a co-optation mechanism, allowing insiders to escape restrictions on board independence (such as by donating to directors’ pet charities), and campaign finance. The upshot is that some sort of legal intervention may be needed. Leaving agency problems totally unregulated in the CP context could create negative spillovers in other contexts.

Finally, the chapter builds on the CP as signaling/co-optation explanations to make the case for some form of mandatory disclosure. Regulating some standardized, comparable, subject-to-liability form of disclosure could facilitate a better-functioning market for reputational rewards. At the same time, exploiting the potential to use undisclosed CP to co-opt governance mechanisms stresses the importance of not leaving CP in the dark. In this respect, legal intervention should focus not only on the levels of prosociality (how much does the company donate), but also on its targets (to whom does the company donate). Mandatory disclosure could therefore also facilitate reputational sanctions for abuses of CP.

The chapter proceeds in four sections. Section 5.2 provides a critical synthesis of the existing literature. Section 5.3 introduces my signaling theory of CP. Section 5.4 clarifies whether and how CP could be a corporate governance problem. Section 5.5 sketches policy implications. Section 5.6 offers concluding thoughts by reevaluating the claim that CP serves as a reputational buffer against reputational sanctions.

  • 5.2 The Extant CP Literature: Data and Theory

5.2.1 Existing Data

We have a good grasp on the magnitude of corporate donations. American companies spend approximately $20.5 billion annually on philanthropy.6 These $20.5 billion amount to 0.9 percent of corporate pre-tax profits.7 While the absolute amounts increase over time, donations as a percentage of profits remain somewhat stable, around 1 percent. At the industry level, pharmaceutical companies give the most.8 At the firm level, the biggest product donors (Pfizer, Merck, Google) evaluate their contributions in billions, while the biggest cash donors (Gilead Sciences, Wells Fargo, Goldman Sachs) each donate around $300 million annually.9 Among the Fortune 100 companies, the median giving is around $63 million annually, and among the top quartile, that number jumps to close to $170 million.10

We also have a good grasp of what exactly companies donate: cash donations are clearly the most dominant form of giving, over product donations or employee release time.11 And on the “who decides” question, it seems that despite a recent trend to put CP policy in the hands of specialized departments and professionals, CEOs still exert a lot of influence over these discretionary expenditures.12

Beyond these stylized facts, the management literature has obsessed over finding a link between CP and the financial bottom line. Does doing good lead to doing well? We can quickly summarize the overarching patterns of this voluminous literature thusly:13 (1) there is a small but positive association between social and financial performance; (2) this association is stronger for CP than for other social performance proxies (such as corporate policies and transparency); and (3) the link from financial to social performance is at least as strong as the reverse (i.e., doing well enables doing good; companies that generate more profits can afford to sacrifice more profits in the public interest).

The main lesson is that, while we cannot conclude that companies do well by doing good, we can conclude that companies can both do well and do good. In other words, there is no evident financial punishment for prosociality.

Things get murkier when we try to go beyond the “in general” question (does giving generally lead to having), and identify the conditions under which CP increases or decreases the value of a given company.14 From a legal scholar perspective, studies linking the quality of corporate governance mechanisms and CP behavior are the most interesting. In theory, if there is a positive correlation between strong governance and CP, then the profit-enhancing approach is supported, and the need for legal intervention decreases. If there is a positive correlation between weak governance and CP, then the agency-costs approach is supported, and the need for intervention increases. Yet so far, empirical studies linking governance to CP remain largely inconclusive and open to interpretation. CP levels positively correlate with some proxies for weak monitoring (e.g., firms with low debt ratios donate more), while negatively correlating with others (firms with more independent boards donate more).15

In summary, our knowledge of CP practices remains in a high level of generality. We know that CP is neither a huge nor an insignificant corporate expenditure, that top managers exert a lot of influence over these ultra-discretionary expenditures, that there is no evidence that prosociality is being punished financially, and that conditions leading to more giving or more profit-minded giving are hard to identify. Mainly, we know that we do not know much. We need better data.16 Importantly, we also need a better theory: better articulation of the mechanisms that might link CP to outcomes that are good or bad for the company.17

5.2.2 Existing Theory

Current theoretical accounts of CP fall under two main categories: the “profit-enhancing approach,” which construes CP as buying goodwill for the company, and the “agency- costs approach,” which views CP as a managerial perk. Both accounts suffer from under-articulation. They do not clearly identify the mechanisms linking CP with enhanced profits or managerial agency costs.

The profit-enhancing approach usually rests on a “delegated philanthropy” assumption: the idea that when companies sacrifice profits, they simply meet the charitable preferences of stakeholders. Stakeholders are willing to pay more for companies that donate, and so when companies donate they increase demand or reduce their operating costs. In other words, stakeholders prefer “nice” companies. When consumers purchase a product from a donating company, they get a bundle of direct utility from consuming, and “warm glow” from buying products that were manufactured by nice companies.18

Yet these delegated philanthropy explanations rely on too-unrealistic assumptions. First, while people are quick to profess in surveys their willingness to pay for nicer companies’ products, evidence of actual buying decisions is rather tenuous.19 Second, even if you believe that declarations in surveys do translate into actions, you cannot conclude that CP is especially effective at buying goodwill. After all, in those surveys consumers profess much stronger preferences for other prosocial expenditures, such as labor and environmental issues, than for cash donations.— Third and perhaps most pertinently, evidence shows that consumers are too often unaware of different levels of CP.21

Finally, even if consumers have meaningful charitable preferences, and even if they are able (i.e., aware of CP levels) to act upon them, one still needs to explain why consumers would want to delegate charity. Instead of paying more for a nice company’s product, consumers can pay for a value-adjusted cheaper product of a non-sacrificing firm. Consumers can then use the cash saved to satisfy their own charitable preferences, which, in all likelihood, differ somewhat from those of the donating company’s managers.—

The agency-costs approach, by contrast, suggests that the seemingly irrational CP phenomenon is completely rational from a corporate decision-maker standpoint. The impetus driving CP behavior is private benefits to corporate insiders. A manager donating with shareholders’ money gets invitations to board seats, tickets to gala events, esteem from her peers, personal satisfaction of her own altruistic preferences, and warm glow.23

One problem with such managerial-utility explanations is that they do not fully explain why managers would choose CP as a channel to reap private benefits, rather than other channels such as negotiating for higher pay/perks. If the manager engages in CP to get warm glow and satisfy her own charitable preferences, she could arguably get more warm glow from negotiating higher pay and then donating the extra dollars in her own name. Indeed, existing data casts doubt on mechanisms that were traditionally offered to link CP to managerial utility. For example, one study found that firms that pay their CEOs more are not the ones donating more, and another found that replacing the CEO does not change the firm’s donating policy.— Another problem with managerial-utility accounts is that they often fail to clearly answer the “so what?” question: assuming CP is indeed driven by managerial utility, is it necessarily bad for the company, the shareholders, or overall welfare?

Both the profit-enhancing and agency-costs approaches therefore suffer from serious theoretical flaws. And the existing empirical evidence on which captures reality better is inconclusive. Even findings presumed to favor one approach can be interpreted to cut both ways, at least until the mechanisms that link CP to company-level and managerial-level benefits are better articulated.— The next two sections attempt to do just that: provide a better explanation of the mechanisms in play.

5.3 CP as a Costly Signaling Mechanism

To illustrate the problem with the buying-goodwill explanation for CP, consider a puzzling pattern identified by a famous study, which tested whether and how prosociality reduces labor costs.26 The buying-goodwill argument generates two hypotheses: (1) companies that donate more will do better at attracting potential job applicants; (2) the abovementioned effect will be mediated by the applicants’ “social preferences.” In other words, applicants who feel strongly about social or environmental issues will be more attracted to prosocial companies. The study’s findings were consistent with the first hypothesis, but inconsistent with the second. Job applicants did consider prosocial companies as more attractive places to work. But the effect was not mediated by the applicants’ social or environmental preferences. Job applicants considered prosocial companies as more attractive to work for, regardless of whether applicants cared about social issues.

This empirical pattern suggests that something else is in play here, beyond the supposed preference for nicer companies. Even strictly profit-minded stakeholders prefer companies that are nice; not because of the niceness per se, but rather because niceness is an indication of something else. The interesting questions are thus: what is prosociality indicative of, and how exactly can prosociality be credibly indicative of other traits?

5.3.1 The Basic Story: Signaling Financial Strength

Our starting premise is that there exists asymmetric information about companies’ underlying attributes. Insiders know more than outsiders. Both have incentives to mitigate the asymmetry. One method for insiders to mitigate asymmetries is to communicate information to target audiences about unobservable qualities through observable activities. This is the basic background of a costly signaling story.27 As applied here, profit sacrificing in general and CP in particular can serve as costly (thereby credible) and observable attributes, conveying messages about unobservable attributes.

Consider for example the potential of using CP to signal future free cash flows. The signaler in our informal model is the company, or, more precisely, its decision-makers (top management in widely held companies, or dominant shareholders). Receivers of the signal - the target audience - are outside investors. One important attribute for how outsiders evaluate the company is future free cash flows. Because future free cash flows are not readily observable by outsiders, they make a plausible subject for costly signaling.28 What could constitute an observable costly attribute that credibly conveys messages about future cash flows? In the current context, big changes in cash donations could fit the bill. Cash donations are costly in an intuitive manner: insiders decide to take a dollar that they could have used to meet the demands of contractual claimants, and instead give it to unrelated third parties. Outsiders that observe a company substantially increasing its expenditures on prosocial profit sacrificing will infer that the company’s insiders perceive their ability to procure future resources as better than was previously evaluated. Outsiders then update their forecasts about the company’s prospects accordingly.

But for such a signal to work, it needs to be more than just costly. It has to be costlier for low-quality companies in order to avoid mimicry (the costs have to be differentiating and quality-dependent). In the current context, cash donations need to be costlier for firms with low future free cash flows than for those with high cash flows. One could argue that companies with low future cash flows can finance a high level of donations out of retained earnings or external finance. If insiders can simply borrow money to raise their CP levels even when times are bad, then outsiders will not change their valuations based on observing CP.

Yet empirical studies showing that corporate goodness is costlier for financially constrained firms refute this argument.— There are several possible reasons behind such a link between corporate goodness and financial constraints. For one, borrowing to finance the donations is costlier for companies with relatively bad future prospects because it requires them to expose themselves to unfavorable covenants or disclosure requirements.— Furthermore, there is evidence that managers care deeply about meeting earnings benchmarks and smoothing earnings, to the extent that they will even sacrifice projects with positive net present value to set aside buffer cash.31 Thus, it is plausible to assume that insiders in low quality firms will find it more costly to spend ultra-discretionary dollars on CP, since they need all the cash buffers they can get. Outsiders observing a large increase in CP levels could therefore infer that insiders know they are not going to be financially constrained.32

Stated differently, the conditions for costly signaling are as follows. First, companies vary in their ability to generate future free cash flows. Second, outside investors cannot readily observe future free cash flows, and stand to gain from knowing more about them. Third, at the same time, outsiders cannot simply believe all direct messages from insiders about future free cash flows; insiders stand to gain from sending exaggerated signals. So, outsiders resort to making inferences based on some observable, costly behaviors of companies, and the fact that the behavior is costly assures the credibility of the signal. Low-quality signalers cannot incur the same amount of costs as high-quality signalers. Fourth, one such observable behavior is explicit profit sacrificing. Big cash donations will carry information about the prospects of the company as long as the costs of donating are negatively correlated with an ability to generate future free cash flows.

If these propositions are plausible, then we can assume that communication through profit sacrificing will be informative. Yet a fully conscious, meditated decision to sacrifice profits with a clear intent to signal financial strength is not needed. When the above propositions apply, we can assume that some “design force” - conscious decision-making, market forces selection, or imitation of successful companies - will instill in CP the tenets of a costly, informative signal of financial strength. But are all these propositions really plausible? The next section elaborates on potential limitations, in order to identify the specific circumstances under which we can expect signaling by conspicuous goodness.

5.3.2 Refining the Basic Story: Limitations

Before concluding that prosocial profit sacrifices bring benefits through signaling, several conditions and limitations need to be addressed. Consider the following four potential limitations.

First, CP is just one of many other signals available. If throwing cash away serves as a signal for an ability to procure resources, why should companies throw it away on charitable organizations? Why not throw it on investors, in the form of dividends?33 Alternatively, why not throw it on conspicuous consumption, such as building luxurious headquarters, or purchasing lavish perks?— All it takes is for a firm to sacrifice profits, so why make the sacrifice in the public interest? The key to answering this question is acknowledging that signaling through prosocial sacrifices does not preclude the use of other signals. In real life, unlike in models, multiple messages are conveyed by multiple means.— The real question, then, is not choosing CP over another expenditure, but what the mix of signals chosen in the given circumstances will be.

Think about the choice between signaling through increasing dividends and signaling through increasing CP expenditures. For most firms, the choice is nonexistent, as they never pay dividends.36 For firms that do pay dividends, and can use dividends as signaling financial strength, it still may make sense to use CP as a backup signal: another signaling channel to convey the same message. Signaling through multiple channels (rather than exaggerating signals through the same channel) makes sense when receivers are prone to err in evaluating signals.37 The corporate environment fits the conditions of an error-prone environment: noisy communications, strong incentives to cheat, widely varying perceptions and preferences of receivers, and accelerating signaling costs.38 A corporate decision maker who wishes to signal good prospects, may supplement the increase in dividends with an increase in CP levels, to make sure that outsiders get the right message (e.g., that outsiders are not attributing an increase in dividends to bowing to pressures from shareholders eager for payouts). While this CP-as-backup-signal speculation is ultimately a matter for future pinpointed empirical research, existing evidence indicates that it is not far-fetched. Firms that pay out more also donate more.39

A second potential criticism is that CP is not costly enough to be a costly signal. To be sure, CP does cost something, but is it truly a handicap to big firms? After all, CP levels in many companies represent only a “modest incremental cash drain on resources available to managers,”— and modest costs cannot differentiate between high- and low-quality signalers. To accommodate this valid objection, we need to refine our predictions regarding benefits arising from signaling. Prosociality will convey credible messages about future financial prospects only when conducted on a large scale relative to a company’s size and resources. Day-to-day marginal contributions are not likely to generate signaling benefits; big changes in CP policy are.41 For example, in March 2008, when Goldman Sachs announced a new $100 million CP program meant to further business education of women in the developing world, outsiders took notice.42 Outsiders were free to infer that Goldman’ s top managers simply cared about the cause of women’ s business education, or that they were hoping to buy goodwill by appearing nice. But outsiders may also have inferred that Goldman’s managers thought that the company could afford to sacrifice profits much more than it had previously because future prospects were looking brighter.43

A third potential criticism would point out that CP is not sticky enough to be an effective signal. If a certain expenditure is completely discretionary, then it cannot be a good signal. Signals need to have some level of stickiness to be reliable because something removable at will is not a true handicap. To accommodate this limitation, we first need to understand that the stickiness of signals is not a binary matter. While CP might be less sticky than other prosocial expenditures (such as reversing expenditures on employees’ working conditions), anecdotal evidence indicates that there is a degree of asymmetric stickiness to CP. Managers enjoy much flexibility when deciding to initiate or raise CP levels, but there are costs to omitting or dropping existing levels. For example, managers fear reputational sanctions and personal pressures from NGOs or social rating indices if the company drops its support.—

A fourth potential limitation of the signaling theory is that prosociality is not observable to outsiders in a timely and useful manner. Although this limitation applies more strongly to operational profit sacrificing than to CP -cash donations in particular are readily communicated and quantified - this is still a strong limitation. Disclosure of CP is unregulated, and this creates an environment in which it is difficult for companies to reliably convey the relative level of their explicit prosociality.45 Though lack of regulation is likely to reduce the benefits from signaling, it will not totally eliminate them. We should think of it as creating conditions for some coarse signaling story: companies wishing to distinguish themselves can voluntarily disclose their conspicuous goodness in a wide and timely manner, but outsiders will be able to distinguish between companies based on their CP levels only when the differences across companies and time are great. Again, the conclusion is that the profit sacrifices most likely to generate signaling benefits are big changes, which are easily communicated to outsiders.

Having accommodated all those considerations, we are now left with a limited, refined story of corporate prosociality as a signal to outside investors. Only sacrifices that are relatively significant in size, readily observable, and not easily reversed can be expected to serve as an effective signal. Granted, these limitations confine the applicability of the signaling story to only a small number of actual CP decisions. Yet it is precisely those few large donations that are practically important; a small number of donations comprise the bulk of overall corporate giving expenditures and raise the most concerns. The signaling-to-investors story is therefore relevant to the more significant and/or controversial cases of CP, and thus merits attention.

Furthermore, even when circumstances make the signaling-to-investors story unlikely, CP can affect the company’s reputation for other attributes, and among other crowds. For example, donating products or employee release-time might be ineffective as signals to investors looking for information on future financial strength, but effective as signals to employees looking for information on management’s commitment to a certain corporate culture. It is these other sorts of signaling stories - signaling to nonfinancial stakeholders - to which we now turn.

5.3.3 Other Possible Stories: Signaling Product Quality or Workplace Attractiveness

The story of corporate donations signaling financial strength is only one of several potential signaling stories. Acts of corporate niceness can also have other informational contents (not just financial strength) and target audiences (not just investors). Consider the following three examples.

First, think about a signaling-to-customers model, where high levels of corporate donations convey information about the quality of the firm’s product.46 Such a model assumes two types of entrepreneurs. One type has other-regarding preferences, and thus cares about externalities, and the other type lacks those preferences and cares only about profits. For the other-regarding types, sacrificing profits is less costly, as they gain warm glow by refraining from externalities. By contrast, for the purely profit-motivated entrepreneurs, CP is a total sacrifice. Accordingly, the model assumes that when customers observe a company engaging in higher CP levels than its competitors, they infer that insiders in this company will be more averse to sacrifice unobservable qualities of products than their competitors are (because sacrificing product quality will generate externalities, which will in turn decrease the other-regarding entrepreneur’s utility).

This CP-as-signaling-product-quality theory addresses some of the flaws in the delegated philanthropy accounts. It argues that CP is value-enhancing not because it satisfies customers’ preferences for nice companies, but rather because it mitigates informational gaps about attributes relevant to the company’s line of business. Yet the specifics of this signaling-to-customers theory still rest on some shaky assumptions. Just like delegated philanthropy explanations, the signaling-to-customers theory assumes that charitable preferences drive corporate behavior - only here, the preferences are those of entrepreneurs rather than consumers. Such an assumption might be plausible in manager-owned, small companies where the entrepreneur is tantamount to the company, but it is less plausible for large impersonal corporations. Further, the theory assumes that information on CP levels can be easily observed and compared by customers who make purchases accordingly, but academic evidence on the ground suggests that consumers’ awareness of CP policies is actually low.—

A second possibility for prosociality to generate signaling benefits is through attracting high-quality employees. This relates to the puzzling empirical pattern discussed above: job applicants preferred prosocial companies regardless of how they felt about prosociality itself.— So what did the level of prosociality teach applicants about the company? Can a company’s niceness boost its reputation for workplace conditions? Why would building a shelter home for the poor improve the company’s reputation for how it treats its employees?

For one, prosociality could have sent a message about a “cooperative” corporate culture. Applicants may figure that top managers who commit to spend more on charity are not solely short-term-profits-hungry. These are the managers that you assume will not fire you or nickel-and-dime you in every chance they get. By explicitly sacrificing profits in the public interest, insiders can credibly and visibly commit to a certain culture, thereby attracting job applicants who will fit the culture.— Note that the signaling-to-workers hypotheses are more relevant in high-quality labor industries, and so in those industries we should expect more CP, all else being equal. Perhaps it is yet another factor explaining the dominance of pharmaceutical and technology companies among the largest corporate donors.

A third example of an alternative signaling story takes us back to investors as the intended audience, but this time with a different message: big increases in CP can convey fundamental information not only about the level of future free cash flows, but also about systematic decreases in riskiness of future cash flows. In other words, observing a big donation can make investors update the denominator rather than the numerator in the discounted cash flow formula. When projections of cash flows become less risky, insiders can make better assessments of their future opportunities and opportunity costs, and can thus better maximize the level of prosocial sacrifices - they need fewer cash buffers. In this respect, prosociality could mitigate asymmetric information about changes along the life cycles of organizations and managerial reactions to those changes.—

5.3.4 Adding Complexity

We have sketched the contours of basic signaling explanations to corporate prosociality. But it is important to note potential layers of complexity that can be followed through in future research, such as the choice between prosocial and wasteful signals, the possibility for errors in signaling, and costs from attracting the wrong reaction.

A necessary condition for costly signaling is that the behavior will be costly to the signaler. But nothing in the model requires the behavior to actually benefit others. The handicap can be prosocial, but it can just as well be wasteful (as in conspicuous consumption). A fuller analysis should thus account for conditions under which prosocial signals are more effective than wasteful ones. For example, if receivers have preferences for prosocial displays and if such displays receive greater attention (known as the “broadcast efficiency” of the signal), then the signaler should prefer them to wasteful handicaps.51 The choice of signals also has policy implications. Society might be better off when corporate signaling is done via prosocial handicaps, rather than wasteful ones52 - think donations versus gold-embroidered shower curtains.

It is also important to take fuller account of errors in signaling communication. We have already mentioned that receivers are error-prone when perceiving signals in noisy environments. Signalers can be error-prone, too. For example, corporate managers are overly optimistic.— When deciding CP levels based on their upwardly biased perception of future prospects, managers might “advertise” too much, that is, engage in too much CP. A bias in forecasting future cash flows erodes the value of the signal and at some point the signaling stops being informative.

Finally, future research could also consider the possibility of another type of cost to the signaler - namely, attracting an unintended observer or provoking an unintended reaction from target audiences. Explicit profit sacrificing is conspicuous, and conspicuousness can attract predators who think that the signaler has too much waste. Activist hedge funds are a case in point. When activist hedge funds observe a company increasing its profit sacrificing, they may decide to target the company because of the slack it obviously possesses. Regardless of whether activist hedge funds are beneficial to overall welfare, incumbent managers usually want to avoid attracting them. Insiders worried about attracting hedge funds could be pushed to choose suboptimal signaling levels ex ante. Future empirical research could try to shed light on this speculation by examining, for example, whether changes in CP policies attract certain investors.

5.3.5 Fit with Evidence

When I started writing about CP as signaling, a decade ago, there was little firm-specific evidence that could lend credibility or discard my hypotheses. I therefore relied mostly on stylized facts and industry-level data, pointing to patterns that were inconsistent with the prevalent delegated philanthropy approach, but consistent with my signaling approach. For example, a signaling-cash-flows theory predicts a higher level of CP in companies and industries where future free cash flows are less readily observable by outsiders, free cash is perceived to be good for the company,54 and other channels for signaling cash flows are blocked or too costly. The fact that pharmaceuticals and technology companies are among the largest donors is consistent with these predictions.55

Another empirical pattern I pointed out that could not be reconciled with the existing approaches is that CP - the most discretionary, explicit form of profit sacrificing - has a stronger association with financial performance than other corporate social performance expenditures. The signaling story, by contrast, fits this empirical pattern. Cash donations are more effective signals than operational profit sacrifices; they are more easily communicated and quantifiable to outsiders. And the fact that they benefit unrelated third parties (i.e., are more explicit sacrifices) means that they are perceived as greater handicaps than operational sacrifices.

Relatedly, existing theories cannot explain the dominance of cash over in-kind donations. Traditional profit-enhancing theories predict that in-kind donations would yield better results than cash donations in terms of tax advantages, better bundling of warm glow with intrinsic utility, and stronger consumer preferences. Yet the opposite is observed: cash donations generate better reputational payoffs.56 Why? I proposed that some of the value enhancement comes from signaling: cash donations are more effective signals because they are easily observable and less open to interpretation.

In recent years, several empirical studies directly tested the signaling hypothesis, and corroborated it. Large-N studies now explicitly state that the signaling hypothesis is a better fit with evidence than the buying goodwill hypothesis.57 A couple of studies explicitly find that cash donations are more strongly related to better financial performance and firm value than in-kind donations.58 Several of my other conjectures remain untested, though: whether conspicuous philanthropic activity attracts hedge funds activism, whether companies operating in an environment with high levels of asymmetric information signal in multiple channels (e.g., both dividends and CP), and so on. These remain avenues for potential future research.

5.4 CP as a Co-optation Mechanism

After examining how CP can be good for the company, let us now understand how CP can also be bad for the company. The existing accounts of the negative sides of CP usually adopt an agency-costs perspective, claiming that managers use shareholders’ money to donate to their own pet charities. While it is not contested that CP is driven to some extent by managerial-utility considerations, there is still a lively debate around the extent, and the implications. We enrich this debate by introducing an oft-ignored distinction between profit-sacrificing expenditures that merely reflect agency costs, and those that actually aggravate agency costs. CP is not really bad for the company if it merely reflects existing problems. It starts being a problem once managers can use their discretion over CP money to weaken corporate governance.

5.4.1 Motivating Examples

It is best to start with a concrete example that illustrates the distinction between problem-reflecting and problem-generating CP: juxtaposing the infamous cases of Occidental Petroleum Co. (Oxy) and Enron. Oxy donated more than $85 million (a third of its annual profits) to a museum named after Armand Hammer, its soon-to-retire CEO. Enron was much more modest; the company donated between $1 and $2 million to a medical center headed by a member of the board audit committee, and several hundred thousand to a think tank that employed another independent director.— Usually, agency explanations of CP lump both instances together. In both cases, decision makers used discretion over corporate profit-sacrificing money to satisfy the preferences of top management. Seen from this angle, the Oxy case is much more detrimental to company and shareholder interests simply because the sacrifice is larger.

But is it really more problematic? In Oxy’s case, the donation was disclosed, as the amount was material enough to mandate disclosure under the securities laws. No adverse impact on stock prices was observed when the sacrifice was announced,— perhaps because the market already anticipated that Armand Hammer controlled the board and could pass decisions on whatever other types of profit sacrificing that he pleased. Arguably, no agency costs were created because of this donation; it only reflected existing agency costs.

By contrast, Enron consistently pursued a CP policy that undermined the checks and balances on corporate governance. Perhaps not surprisingly, its donations were not disclosed. The direct hit to the financial bottom line from those donations was insignificant, but what mattered more than the levels of the donations were the targets of the donations. The choice of targets made it somewhat less likely that the CEO would be asked tough questions later. In my view, these latter types of donations represent a corporate governance problem justifying legal intervention even more than the former type of pure self-aggrandizement.

The Enron case illustrates the possibility that managers will use their discretion to sacrifice profits to entrench themselves and weaken the mechanisms that monitor them. It therefore pokes holes in the existing debate. A generic objection to the “CP-is-bad-for-the-company” arguments rests on a “fixed appropriation” logic. Say a manager used company’s money to donate to her favorite charity. Such a donation does not hurt shareholders, as long as we assume managerial discretion is capped by market and/or contractual mechanisms. If managerial discretion is not limitless, then increased use of discretion to sacrifice profits prosocially may come at the expense of other managerial expenditures, such as executive pay and perks. Benefits that managers achieve through CP will offset other forms of managerial appropriation.61 Scholars have attacked the fixed appropriation argument on various grounds.62 What the Enron example illustrates is a different (nonexclusive) rebuttal: CP as co-optation, to which we turn next.

5.4.2 Mechanisms of Co-optation

Managerial discretion in an unregulated channel like CP can be used to co-opt those in charge of monitoring. Let us focus on three governance mechanisms: using CP money to co-opt independent directors, influence politicians, and ally with activist stakeholders.

The first channel through which CP can generate agency costs is co-optation of board independence. The point here is that managers use CP not merely to donate to their own pet charities, but also to donate to the pet charities of those who are supposed to monitor the mangers. This pattern is not limited to the Enron case. Look to other postmortem analyses of failed governance mechanisms and you will find similar tactics in play. Ross Johnson did it at RJR Nabisco,63 Conrad Black at Hollinger,64 and Dennis Kozlowski at Tyco,65 to name but a few. As board independence has become a governance panacea,66 the attractiveness of CP as a backdoor channel to influence directors without losing their “independent” tag will likely only increase.67

A second mechanism that makes CP a corporate governance issue is the use of money designated as CP to influence politics. The ability and willingness of corporations to use CP in politics is especially relevant today. In the aftermath of the Citizens United v. FEC— decision, there has been a lively discussion in Congress, the SEC, and legal academia on the need to introduce protective mechanisms for explicit political spending. Not enough attention, however, has been directed to the possibility of bypassing protective mechanisms through corporate donations to tax-exempt “charitable” organizations that serve as conduits for political influence; that is, implicit political spending. CP is relatively unregulated, so managers have incentives to couch political spending as CP in order to evade restrictions on explicit political donations.

The means exist to effectuate this managerial will. While under IRC § 501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations may not legally engage in political activity, there is ample room to characterize political activity as “educational,” thus maintaining an organization’s tax-exempt status. Two notable ways to engage in politicized CP are: first, funding think tanks that qualify as educational organizations while de facto supporting very specific policies or politicians. And, second, supporting classic advocacy organizations (also known as § 501(c) (4) organizations) with CP money, through the “c3/c4 split” (i.e., lobbying organizations establishing a complementary tax-exempt entity that is heavily funded by corporations).— Indeed, a recent strand of empirical studies managed to spotlight the usage of covert political activities.— One study in particular shows that firms use charitable contributions through their foundations as a tax-exempt lobbying mechanism. The use of CP as lobbying, they conclude, amounts to over $ 1 billion a year - much more than lobbying through political action committees (PACs).71

A separate question is whether usage of CP as a covert political influence mechanism is bad for shareholders. If insiders use their clout over politicians to further favorable policies, then society as a whole may suffer, but the shareholders of a given company may actually value the purchase of political clout with CP money. Yet managers can also use political donations to further narrow, managerial interests, such as lowering investor protection. Consider the case of managerial lobbying for anti-takeover legislation. When Dayton Hudson, a Minnesota corporation, became a target for takeover in 1987, the managers convinced the state to hold a special legislative session where the company’s charitable record was used as consideration for enacting a new anti-takeover bill.— More generally, when diversified shareholders hold the market portfolio, and managers use CP money to purchase policies that favor one company at the expense of another, then CP expenditures amount to a transfer with deadweight costs.73

A third, less intuitive use of CP to generate further agency costs is as a subtle anti-takeover mechanism. Managers can invest strategically in profit sacrificing in order to gain support from activists, such as consumer groups or public pension funds. Those activists are then expected to return the favor by reducing the probability of CEO turnover. Even if a potential raider can increase a company’s value, activist stakeholders will have incentives to keep incumbent managers in place, as long as incumbents credibly commit to continue investing in specific social or environmental issues. Activists can use nonconventional “voice” mechanisms - mounting a media campaign, threatening boycotts, or using their political clout - to support incumbents and fend off takeovers.

The empirical studies that support the prosociality as entrenchment hypothesis— focus on operational profit sacrificing (as in moving to a greener production to appease environmental groups). For our purposes, the question is can managers gain personal favor with activists also by donating to charity? Anecdotal evidence suggests they can.75 In the Minnesota anti-takeover bill, for example, Dayton Hudson’s CP policy was not merely touted as valuable; the incumbents also called upon the company’s grantees - apparently key players in the state - to help promote managerial lobbying efforts.— More generally, the CP-as-co-optation idea can explain why firms with independent boards donate more. If profit sacrificing is a managerial perk, then arguably managers who are monitored by independent boards should engage in it less. But if CP is not only self-aggrandizing but also entrenching, then managerial-driven CP should only increase when internal governance is stronger (e.g., when boards are more independent). Under a greater internal threat to their authority, managers need to invest more in maintaining influence (a demand-side explanation). Unregulated managerial discretion over prosocial expenditures is therefore more likely to be

used in such contexts as another tool to influence key players, whose support managers need more when threatened from within.

*

Throughout this book, our analysis has followed two steps: understanding how reputation works in a given market, and then examining how the law affects reputation. This chapter has focused thus far on the first prong: how reputational incentives push companies to engage in CP. We now move to the second prong: how the law shapes both the signaling and co-optation aspects of CP behavior.

5.5 How the Law Affects CP: the Case for Disclosure

Legal systems across the world have afforded wide discretion to corporate managers to sacrifice profits in the public interest, while very few protective mechanisms apply. In the United States, for example, companies do not even have to disclose their CP activity. This legal treatment may have been a consequence of viewing the buying goodwill mechanism as extremely simple: companies donate because stakeholders like the fact that companies donate. Companies can increase profits by acting philanthropically, and if CP increases profits, then there is no need to intervene. Nonexistent legal regulation may also be a consequence of a simplified view of the critical accounts of CP as agency costs. The agency approach assumes that managers will always have some discretionary resources to spend as they wish, as totally eliminating agency costs is simply too costly (monitoring managers is imperfect). Given this level of discretionary resources at the managers’ disposal, it should be of no consequence to shareholder value whether managers choose to spend on their preferred charity or on traveling in luxurious company jets. Moreover, the understanding goes, these expenditures are insignificant in dollar terms and thus do not merit intervention.

Yet once we introduce the CP-as-signaling and the CP-as-co-optation approaches, the case for some form of intervention - particularly, mandatory disclosure - becomes stronger. As this section shows, here as well, legal intervention can actually facilitate better reputational control of the positive and negative aspects of CP. Section 5.1.1 details the existing legal structure for regulating CP, in the United States and elsewhere. Section 5.1.2 then clarifies what we should not do, namely, ban CP. Section 5.1.3 provides the case for what we should do: implement some form of mandatory disclosure. Section 5.1.4 offers some political economy thoughts on why past efforts to legislate disclosure requirements have failed.

5.5.1 The Existing Regime: a Regulatory Vacuum

The reputation-through-litigation story does not apply in the corporate niceness context, simply because there is very little litigation. In most developed countries, the law grants corporations the power to engage in philanthropy, and allows managers wide discretion in exercising this power.77 Only rarely do shareholders challenge management’s decision to donate. When they do, the courts are quick to assume that managers decided to donate with some long-term benefit for the company in mind.78 And donating to charity would not constitute “waste,” because managers can practically always justify profit sacrifices by alluding to some indirect benefit.

To the extent that the law affects reputational incentives to donate, it does so through a different channel: not litigation but rather disclosure rules. Some countries have installed detailed disclosure rules, requiring companies to reveal the amounts they donated, or the beneficiaries.— The United States, by contrast, does not subject CP to a specific disclosure requirement.— The only resemblance of disclosure requirements comes from private ordering: the top stock exchanges demand that a listed company that donates over a certain amount to a charity affiliated with an independent director disclose this contribution.— Yet such soft-law requirements are rarely enforced.

The upshot is that CP practices exist in the United States in a regulatory vacuum. The laws evolved to grant wide discretion to sacrifice profits prosocially, without affording investors the means to control this discretion, such as by mandatory disclosure or a shareholder vote.82 Armed with insights on the circumstances under which CP can be either good or bad for the company, we can now assess whether not regulating at all is optimal. Here as well, there are two layers to the optimality question: how the law affects behavior directly, by sanctioning certain behaviors, and how the law affects behavior indirectly, by producing information.

5.5.2 The Case against Banning CP

Would we be better off with a legal regime that directly intervenes and bans CP? The answer is clearly no. The body of literature studying the link between CP and the financial bottom line tells us there at the minimum there is no financial penalty for CP. A blanket legal ban cannot be justified on economic grounds.

The next option to consider is a targeted ban: sanctioning certain types of CP behaviors. After all, we saw that certain CP practices do not enhance company’s value but rather benefit managers at shareholders’ expense. Those opposing legal intervention frequently respond that, while some donations are indeed about managerial self-aggrandizement, those are only isolated cases of relatively small magnitude that do not merit intervention. Yet, Section 5.4 shed light on the problems that arise from continuing to ignore CP. In the subset of cases in which managerial-driven CP not only reflects existing agency costs but also generates additional agency costs, the case for legal intervention is much stronger. Failure to address agency problems in CP decisions might make it more difficult to address agency problems in other corporate decisions.

But is it really feasible to target and ban those CP decisions that are bad for the company and allow all others? Probably not. Our discussion of the signaling benefits of CP highlights how a targeted ban may be impractical and unwarranted. Shareholders and courts will have a hard time distinguishing profit-enhancing from profit-reducing donations. Sacrificing profits may still be value enhancing, if it constitutes a handicap - a costly signal that mitigates asymmetric information. Attempting to eliminate bad CP decisions based on the existence of clear signs of quid pro quo, or professed insiders’ motivations, is therefore futile.

Still, it is one thing to refrain from direct interference with CP decisions (as we should), and another to leave CP in a regulatory vacuum (as we should not). The optimal regulation of CP seems to be leaving profit-sacrificing discretion to managers, while helping the market check managerial discretion, by providing some form of mandatory disclosure.

5.5.3 The Case for Disclosure

The lack of any substantive disclosure requirement in the United States is not due to omission. Proposals for legislation have been brought up frequently in Congress and the corporate and securities law literature starting in the 1990s.— Yet those proposals, even the modest ones, never made it into law.84 By delving into the legislative history of these proposed disclosure bills, we can distill the arguments made against disclosure into three categories: (1) the direct costs of implementing disclosure; (2) the expected chilling effect on overall CP; and (3) the marginal benefits of regulated disclosure - the relevant information is already public and/or no one is interested in it. A closer look reveals that all three arguments are shaky.

The first argument invokes the costs of compiling and disseminating data. Yet in practice, introducing a new disclosure requirement will not add significantly to the mix of costs already incurred. Firms are required to report the levels and targets of certain donations to the IRS, so no compiling costs would be added.85 Since large firms disseminate information about their prosocial behavior to the public via company websites and separate, lengthy CSR reports, no disseminating costs will be added either.

The second argument suggests that disclosure will decrease the overall levels of CP. Managers will simply steer away from the unwanted distraction that may come with disclosure, and keep their CP engagement to minimum. Any benefits that shareholders may get from sunlight disinfecting bad CP decisions will be dwarfed by the negative impact that too much sun will have on the nonprofit sector. I elaborated elsewhere on why such chilling-effect argument is inconsistent with logic.86 Let us focus here on why it is also inconsistent with evidence. While the United States never experienced mandatory CP disclosure, other countries had, and we can tap their experience for evidence on the real-world consequences of enacting disclosure.

The Israeli experience, for example, suggests that requiring disclosure results in ratcheting up CP levels rather than chilling them. In 2001, the Israeli Securities Authority (ISA) introduced a new reporting requirement, requiring firms to disclose in their annual reports (in the directors’ report section) the amount of money given to charities, as well as the strategy behind to whom did they donate. Following the new regulation, firms disclosed more and, importantly, actually donated more.87 Further, media coverage of CP numbers and policies increased, and the first CSR ratings was established.88 The head of the ISA summed its experience with CP reporting in retrospect thusly: “[mandating CP disclosure] promoted a ‘competition’ among publicly-traded firms, whereby they increased their social involvement.”—

The UK experience completes the picture, by providing us with a glimpse into what happens when a country shifts from a mandatory- to a voluntary-disclosure regime. After the regulator dropped the mandatory disclosure requirement of CP in 2013, companies disclosed less, and, importantly, donated less.— Both the Israeli and the UK example suggest that requiring disclosure of CP actually ramps up, rather than chills, overall CP levels.

The third recurring objection to requiring disclosure of CP posits that investors simply are not interested in information about CP, and those investors who are interested can assemble the relevant pieces of public information without needing regulatory intervention. In support of this claim, opponents of disclosure invoke the relative dearth of shareholder litigation and proposals on the matter. But all we can really conclude from such evidence is that shareholders are not interested in the information currently available. Naturally, the abuse of profit-sacrificing expenditures will not be disclosed voluntarily, so shareholders and regulators cannot act upon them ex ante. A more relevant question is whether the managers of Enron and RJR Nabisco could have freely used CP as a co-optation device if there had been a disclosure requirement in place at the time.91 And as for learning everything investors need to know from existing public reports, it is true that by now virtually all large companies generate detailed CSR reports, yet these reports achieve no real transparency.92 In an uninformative “cheap talk” environment, practically all companies profess to be nice, and no manager professes to abuse CP money to entrench herself, so outsiders cannot distinguish between nice guys and pretenders.

The upshot is that some form of regulated disclosure could better align CP practices with shareholder value. Firms cannot be expected to voluntarily provide sufficient and comparable information on their prosocial activities, due to agency and coordination problems.93

Agency problems mean that, when left on their own, insiders will have incentives to provide biased disclosure, whether by exaggerating the positive aspects of donations or by camouflaging the negative aspects. Mandatory disclosure could serve as an early warning by flushing out cases of self-aggrandizement, as well as reducing the ability of managers to use CP as a co-optation device.

Coordination problems mean that when each firm makes its individual, voluntary disclosure decisions, it does not take into account the positive externalities that come from producing information that facilitates comparisons to other firms. Mandatory disclosure could standardize both the form and the substance of the information, thereby allowing comparing among different companies’ donations, and increasing the value of information to outsiders.

For all these reasons, I do not take the direct-costs objection, the chilling-effect objection, or the no-one-cares objection seriously. Yet there is another, valid objection to requiring CP disclosure, namely, the risk of overwhelming investors with information. Proposing disclosure is too easy of a solution, for academics and policymakers alike, across all types of issues. As a result, the market is already bombarded with disclosure requirements of various kinds. At the same time, the attention span and cognitive capacities of intended audiences do not expand - they remain bounded. Therefore, any piece of added mandatory disclosure, even if valuable in end of itself, crowds out attention to an existing disclosure in another area, perhaps even more valuable. In other words, adding disclosure requirements come with negative externalities, which should be weighed against the presumed benefits of said disclosure.94

Yet, acknowledging the already-existing flow of social responsibility information discredits the “information overload” argument as well. On the contrary, because the mass of public information is currently presented in a distorted, nonstandardized, and nontransparent manner (anecdotes instead of comparable numbers, forcing readers to wind through the maze of long CSR reports), any requirement that companies publicize a standardized and concise form, such as a single number of overall donations, will not muddy the waters but rather crystallize them.

5.5.4 How Come Disclosure Proposals Never Made It into Law?

Given that the commonly raised objections to disclosure do not have enough merit, why do proposals that would require disclosure of CP continue to be rejected? While this was not the original focus of my research, I came out with a surprising political economy story based on personal interviews I conducted, and reading congressional hearings: among those pushing against disclosure were the charitable organizations themselves.

While some nonprofit organizations publicly supported disclosure, leaders of the mainstream foundations and associations were vocal in their resistance. Publicly, they professed their concern that disclosure would yield a chilling effect (an objection we dismissed above). But perhaps there is a cynical flavor to their opposition: what those players care about might not be the level of overall CP, but rather the share of CP directed at their own specific nonprofits. They might fear that disclosure would hinder their advantage in influencing corporate insiders behind closed doors.

From the point of view of the third sector as a group, however, regulated disclosure would likely improve things. In the existing unregulated disclosure regime, companies that actually invest heavily in prosociality find it hard to distinguish themselves from those who merely pretend to be generous. This cheap-talk environment leads insiders to invest in marketing rather than actual philanthropic impact. In other words, prosocial activities are picked for their window-dressing value. Some form of regulated disclosure could lead to less cacophony, and less cacophony could lead to more incentives to engage in meaningful prosocial profit sacrificing.

*

Overall, the corporate governance concerns raised by CP should not be overstated. There are other agency problems more urgent than misuse of prosocial discretion. The legal system does not need to interfere too much with existing practices. At the same time, misuses of CP could be indicative of agency problems and, when used in tandem with other co-optation devices, could generate agency problems. Introducing a limited form of the less restrictive protective mechanism - mandatory disclosure - may therefore be the best option. Whatever form of regulation is introduced, careful attention has to be paid to its expressive aspects. Intervention should be couched as not interfering with voluntary sacrifices and not taming corporate prosociality, so as not to crowd out motivations and erode benefits arising from signaling.95

*

The argument against disclosure run into a common flaw that we have seen throughout this book in various context: not accounting enough for how laws affect reputational concerns. While corporate prosociality is very much a product of reputational incentives, these reputational forces do not operate in a vacuum. They are rather influenced by the existing legal regime. The law dictates the quantity and quality of information on CP activities. Without a background of legal standards governing prosocial disclosure, reputational forces are limited in their ability to ensure that companies engage meaningfully in prosocial activities and report accurately.96 For reputational forces to work their magic, they need legal control of the flow of information. Particularly, they need a one-two punch: ex ante regulation requiring standardized reporting of form and substance, and ex post liability threat for falsely communicating or failing to report. Injecting some form of legal control would increase the threat of reputational sanctions for managers abusing CP expenditures, as well as the promise of reputational rewards, allowing firms to credibly commit to prosociality with real impact.97

5.6 Final Thoughts: Corporate Philanthropy as a Reputational Buffer

While this chapter focused on how CSR helps companies reap reputational rewards, much of the writing on CSR over the past decade has focused on the other side, namely, how CSR serves as a buffer against reputational sanctions. When stakeholders perceive company X as nice, they will give it the benefit of a doubt when bad news breaks, or so the argument goes. Recall the Odwalla contaminated juice story crisis from Chapter 2: because the company had a preexisting image of a do-gooder, stakeholders believed that top management could not have prevented the harm, and the reputational fallout was initially contained.

However, careful studies have questioned the CSR-as-buffer argument. Prior nice-guy reputation works as a buffer only in limited scenarios. It may provide you with the initial benefit of a doubt, but it only lasts that long: if credible damning information about you comes out, it will violate stakeholders’ high expectations from you, and the reputational sanction will actually be bigger.— Further, bad news about a nice company would attract more media coverage and NGOs, because of the man-bite-dog aspect to it.99

From our perspective, the interesting question is how the law shapes companies’ incentives to engage in CP to minimize reputation risk. We can point out three potential effects.

First, the legal system can shape the baseline tradeoffs, between investing in CP as a reputational buffer and reducing one’s legal and reputational risk in other ways. To illustrate, consider the case of a chemical company that stumbles upon a profitable-yet-dangerous chemical, and faces a choice between investing in abatement measures ex ante, and investing in a nice-guy buffer that will supposedly limit the reputational fallout ex post (once bad news about the pollution breaks).— The higher the expected legal sanction, the more the company has incentives to invest in actual abatement of pollution instead of buffering reputational fallouts.

Second, the law can determine whether the nice-guy image serves as a buffer or more as an amplifier. When bad news breaks about a supposedly nice company, that company can build on its preexisting reputational cache and try to convince stakeholders to give it the benefit of a doubt. Yet, the sooner litigation and regulatory investigations start producing information about what and how things happened, the less this benefit of a doubt lasts, and the more likely it is that stakeholders will view what happened as a violation of their expectations.

Finally and similarly to our analysis in Section 5.5, the legal system affects the CP-as-buffer dynamics via disclosure rules. In a country with an effective disclosure regime, which facilitates standardization and comparisons, companies have incentives to go beyond mere appearance management and truly become more socially responsible, so as not to be exposed as hypocrite and have their investment in CP turns into a double-edged sword.

You probably sense the overarching theme by now. In all three channels, when legal deterrence is nonexistent, appearance management becomes key; but when legal deterrence matters, appearance management is not enough. In other words, the more effective legal deterrence is, the less effective CSR becomes as a window-dressing reputational buffer.
