6

Regulators' Reputation

6.1 Introduction

Can judicial review effectively check regulators’ behaviors? The answer largely depends on how regulators behave - what motivates them. If, as in traditional economic theory, regulators mostly maximize their narrow self-interest, then there is little that judicial review can do to stop regulatory capture. Judges may invalidate specific regulatory decisions after the fact, but they cannot overcome the inherent advantages that special interests enjoy in the way of offering lucrative future business opportunities or campaign financing. If, however, regulators care not just about material incentives, but also about their reputation, then judicial review can shape regulators’ behavior indirectly, by providing information on how regulators behave. Regardless of whether courts intervene and strike down specific regulatory decisions or not, the process of litigation can generate reputational pressures that propel the regulators to change their behavior. Judicial review mitigates the risks of regulatory capture not so much through modifying regulators’ material incentives, but rather through shaping the public 's perceptions of regulators.

In other words, the gist of this book’s main argument applies not just in the context of corporate reputation, but also in the context of regulators’ reputation. A burgeoning political science literature empirically documents that regulators care about reputation and proactively react to what the media writes about them. With this literature as our background, we can ask the prior question, of what shapes the media agenda. What regulatory issues the media will cover? How it will cover them? In the regulatory arena, much like in the business world, a large part of the answer is the legal system. Litigation produces information that shapes what we think about regulators.

The most intuitive channel for information about regulators is administrative litigation, which implicates regulatory behavior directly, as in requiring the regulator to provide detailed explanations for why she decided the way she did. A less intuitive channel is private litigation, which implicates regulatory behavior indirectly, as in when a tort law defendant raises the regulatory compliance defense, and turns the trial into a referendum on the regulator’s standard-setting abilities. Information from litigation mitigates the asymmetries that usually exist between the well-informed special interest groups and the hitherto-uninformed dispersed public. It thereby helps the public shame regulators into standing up to powerful interests.

This chapter proceeds in five sections. Section 6.2 synthesizes insights from the burgeoning literature on regulators’ reputation concerns. The section explains why the fact that regulators care about reputation does not necessarily mean that they will do a better job in protecting the public interest. There exists an asymmetric monitoring problem: special interest groups are better at monitoring regulators’ behaviors and spotlighting mistakes against them, while the dispersed public is often unaware or unable to spotlight mistakes. As a result, counterintuitively, a regulator who cares about her reputation will tend to err on the side of the regulated industry and against the public.

Section 6.3 argues that judicial review mitigates the asymmetric monitoring problem, therefore reducing the risk of regulatory capture. The section emphasizes the importance of reason-giving requirements in facilitating bottom-up monitoring of regulators. At the same time, public litigation is more limited in its ability to affect change via reputational pressures than private litigation, for various reasons that the section details. In most circumstances, then, reputational pressures on regulators will have to come from elsewhere.

This is where Section 6.4 enters, extending the argument by focusing on how private litigation (to which the regulator is not even privy) can affect the

regulator’s reputation, pushing her to promote the public interest. Section 6.4 maps typical scenarios where private litigants have incentives to generate information that implicates the regulators’ behavior. The section then revisits the “regulation through litigation” literature, by emphasizing the distinction between information-producing and reputation-shaping effects.

Section 6.5 sketches policy implications, such as identifying the types of cases where judicial activism makes more sense. Section 6.6 finishes with big-picture observations on the differences between the reputational effects of public law litigation and those of private law litigation.

6.2 Regulators' Reputation Concerns

We can define regulators’ reputation in similar fashion to how we defined corporate reputation: the set of beliefs that the regulator’s audiences hold regarding her capabilities, performances, and roles.1 The political science literature examines the questions of whether regulators care about their reputation (they do), why they care about it (because it helps them secure autonomy and power), and how they manage it (by prioritizing salient threats). Yet we still know relatively little about the “so what” question: does the fact that regulators care about reputation mean that they will be more effective, promoting the public interest? Does reputational deterrence work in the regulatory context? This section provides reasons for skepticism. Regulators’ reputations may be too noisy and detached from reality to provide optimal deterrence. A regulator who cares about her reputation will not necessarily do a better job promoting the public interest.

6.2.1 Regulators Care about Reputation

Answering the first question - whether regulators care about reputation - is straightforward: yes. Very much so. With the exception of a few public choice accounts,2 by now most political scientists acknowledge that regulators care about more than just their narrow self-interest. Regulators want to do a good job. And they want to be perceived as doing a good job.3 When deciding how to design, implement, and enforce policy, regulators frequently consider appearances. They think strategically about how their decisions will be perceived by the politicians who appoint them, the public whose interests they are supposed to protect, the industry whom they are supposed to monitor, and so on.

A fast-emerging literature dubbed BRT (for “bureaucratic reputation theory”) has shifted attention to the second question, namely, how regulators care about reputation. The BRT literature empirically documents how regulators proactively manage their reputations, and prioritize their responses to external signals/criticisms.4 For example, some studies show that regulators react differently based on the content of the allegations they are facing: prioritizing allegations of under-regulating over allegations of over-regulating.5 Other studies show that regulators react differently based on the visibility of allegations: they prioritize addressing criticisms that make it to front-page media coverage.6 The BRT literature also documents the arsenal that regulators employ in managing their reputation: they can react to external threats by changing their enforcement decisions, or by changing their communication strategy. Within their communication strategy, under certain conditions regulators respond to allegations by keeping silent, while under other conditions they are more likely to openly address allegations.

We can also tap the BRT literature for insights on the third question, namely, why exactly regulators care so much about reputation. Regulators carefully manage their reputation not just due to concerns about higher prestige and status. A good reputation provides regulators with more autonomy and discretion.7 It buffers them from political attacks, and helps them secure higher budgets.8 After all, politicians are more likely to vest resources and authority in regulators who are perceived to be expert and effective. Further, an agency that enjoys a good reputation can recruit and retain higher-quality public servants. And an individual regulator who enjoys good reputation is more likely to secure promotions. Good reputation also helps regulators with their interactions with the industry they are supposed to regulate or the consumer groups they are meant to protect.9

Still, one interesting question remains understudied: what does it mean that regulators care about their reputation? How do regulators’ reputation concerns affect regulatory behavior? Political scientists too often allude to regulators’ reputation concerns positively, as a trump card against arguments of regulatory capture.10 These scholars assume that the need to maintain a good reputation imposes discipline on regulators. A regulator who cares about her reputation would think twice before conceding to special interests, out of fear that the deal she strikes with them will be exposed and her reputation lost, or so the argument goes. Regulators are aware of the old adage: it takes years to build a strong reputation, but one revealed misbehavior to destroy it. As a result, they will be extra careful about catering to special interests, because one piece of bad news may irreversibly damage their reputation.—

Such reputation-concerns-cure-all argument is flawed. It is one thing to acknowledge that regulators care about reputation, and another to assume that reputational concerns push regulators toward the public interest. As the previous chapters showed, in commercial markets reputations are too often noisy and fail to deter misbehavior or reward good behavior. Similar dynamics are in play in the regulatory context, albeit with some interesting twists.

6.2.2 Regulators’ Reputations Are Noisy

Regulators’ reputations are noisy. A regulator could promote the public interest and get a bad reputation, or cater to special interests and get a good reputation. As a result, reputational concerns do not necessarily promote better regulatory behavior. A responsive regulator does not always respond to the right signals. The same basic flaws that plague the process of reputational judgments in other contexts appear in the regulatory context as well, and with a vengeance.

6.2.2.1 Players Who Dispense Reputational Sanctions

When we think about policymakers’ target audiences, we normally think about the public: the classic reputational sanction in politics would be voting you out if you did not meet expectations. On paper, the fear of not being reelected or reappointed should drive regulators to cater to voters’ preferences. Yet in reality, voters often lack the information necessary to judge whether economic regulators “misbehaved.”— Voters do not have the ability or incentives to keep themselves informed. In a modern-day economy, the apparatus of socioeconomic regulation is all encompassing, detailed, and complex. For the average citizen, remaining informed on whether regulator X did a good job or not is a Herculean task. Remaining wninformed is actually the rational thing to do: while the public as a whole benefit if the polity is informed enough to keep decision makers honest, the private costs of becoming informed dwarf the private benefits. This is the famous rational ignorance problem.13

In fact, in political markets the problem may be more severe. In commercial markets, misjudging reputations can come back to haunt you immediately, as in buying from a shady company or not buying from a great company. In politics, by contrast, you have very little skin in the game. Each voter knows that her single vote is not likely to sway policies. To use Bryan Caplan’s terminology, voters suffer not just from rational ignorance but also from rational irrationality.— That is, voters feel free to indulge their biases when collecting information and voting on policies: I can vote with my favorite team, regardless of whether this team offers the best policies. A voter would feel free to identify certain bad policy choices as praiseworthy and good policy choices as blameworthy, and not suffer the consequences of misjudging.

A different type of target audience is the elected officials who appoint regulators. Ministers are arguably much better informed than the average voter is. Yet politicians, too, often lack the proper information and expertise to judge regulators’ reputation effectively. After all, informational and expertise problems push politicians to delegate policy to professional bureaucrats to begin with. The same problems would likely hinder the ability of politicians to monitor professional bureaucrats after the fact.

6.2.2.2 Players Who Facilitate Reputational Sanctions (Information Intermediaries)

In the political realm, the relevant information intermediaries (those who select, certify, and diffuse information on regulatory behavior) usually fall into two categories: mass media and interest groups. On paper, both have better access to information and more expertise than the public. Yet evidence shows that both rarely cover the meaningful aspects of regulatory behavior, or cover them in a slanted way.

Much like media coverage of big business, media scrutiny of big government is slanted due to dependence on sources and advertisers.— Even if journalists manage to overcome their own biases and lack of expertise, they still need to cater to their readers’ (-voters) biases. Voters are interested in topics that are vivid and discernable, and opinions that fit their own priors.16 Media scrutiny of regulatory behavior is therefore very selective - the media picks its battles according to entertainment value and not according to the issue’s real impact on society.17

Importantly, media coverage of regulatory issues is slanted in hidden ways. The problem is not so much with how the media covers a certain regulatory issue, but with all the issues that the media does not cover.18 Major regulatory agencies, even those that preside over huge budgets and responsibilities, often do not have any reporter assigned to their beat (i.e., no one covers them regularly).— This media-slant-by-omission problem represents a key weakness in the BRT literature: existing studies document how regulators react to what the media covers, but they do not (cannot) document what the media does not cover. To better understand how reputational concerns shape regulatory behavior we first need to understand who sets the media agenda: who and what makes certain regulatory behaviors more vivid and coverable for the media. (Without forecasting too much, a large part of the answer is litigation.)

The other type of information intermediary that can facilitate reputational sanctions for regulators are interest groups. Yet not all interest groups are created equal. Narrow-interest groups are better at squawking when a regulator is about to hurt their interests than public interest groups are.20 Certain types of information on regulatory behavior tend to be more immediately and widely diffused than others.

The example of regulating rates of return illustrates.21 When regulators wish to prevent monopolies from overpricing consumers, they sometimes set a maximum price, based on a formula of the costs to the monopolist firm. On paper, whenever the costs change, the regulator should update the allowed rate of return. In reality, there is an asymmetry: whenever the costs go up, regulated entities trigger a review, and the regulator updates the rate of return upwards. By contrast, when the costs go down, no one triggers an update of the maximum rate of return. In Israel, for example, regulators set in the mid-1990s a rate-of-return formula across sectors, at a time when the general interest rate was in double digits. When the interest rate dropped to 1 percent in the 2000s, no one triggered an update of the formula, rendering price controls completely ineffective.22

The upshot is that, beyond the asymmetric information problem we recognized earlier, there is also an asymmetric monitoring problem. Some groups monitor the regulator’s behavior more diligently.

Recognizing asymmetric monitoring dynamics leads to a counterintuitive and troubling conclusion: a regulator who cares about her reputation would tend to err in favor of the industry and against the public interest. To see why, imagine that you are a publicly spirted regulator. You know that you are bound to make mistakes at some point, given the complexity and uncertainty inherent in modern markets. The question you are asking yourself is how the outside world will perceive my mistakes. Will they spotlight, remember, and hold the mistakes against me? Or will they ignore and forget them? You quickly realize that mistakes against the regulated entities are immediately noticed by an army of dedicated and expert industry people; while mistakes against the public seldom get noticed.23 To paraphrase the philosophical question about a tree falling in the forest when no one is around (did it really make a sound?): if a regulator makes a mistake at the expense of the diffuse public, did she really hurt her reputation? Erring in favor of the regulated industry minimizes the chances that people will notice your (real or perceived) mistakes, saving you from criticism.—

6.2.2.3 Players Who Suffer Reputational Sanctions (the Regulators)

The BRT literature shows that regulators do not take expected reputational sanctions as given. They rather proactively manage the information environment to make themselves appear better than they truly are. For instance, one study shows that regulators prioritize responding to the more visible criticisms. A regulator will prioritize responding to a marginal issue covered in the front pages, even at the expense of more important issue covered only at the back pages.25 Another study finds that regulators fight off reputational threats with communication strategies (what they say) rather than with actions (what they actually do). They would rather talk their way out of criticism. Yet another study shows that regulators who face reputational pressures simply choose less visible ways to concede to special interests (but concede nevertheless).26 In other words, regulators take care of what is risky for regulators; not necessarily what is risky for society.27 Regulators’ ability to manage the information environment reduces the effectiveness of reputational deterrence.

*

The bottom line will sound familiar to readers of the previous chapters: when left on its own, the market for regulators’ reputation is too flawed to consistently deter misbehavior. Yet in reality, the market for regulators’ reputation is rarely left alone. Litigation - both public and private - generates credible information on how regulators behave. The next two sections elaborate.

6.3 How Judicial Review Impacts Regulators' Reputation

The administrative law literature tends to focus on what courts do - whether they interfere with regulatory decisions or not - rather than on how regulators react— To answer how regulators react, one needs a developed theory of how regulators behave, including how reputational concerns affect regulators. If we merge the insights from the BRT literature (on how reputation matters for regulators), with the insights developed thus far in this book (on how litigation affects reputation), we get a part of the answer: regulators anticipate that being challenged in court, regardless of the legal outcome, may alter what their audiences think about them. Judicial review therefore affects regulators not just by modifying their material incentives (as in conventional economic analysis), but also by shaping the public’s perceptions of them.

6.3.1 The Basic Story

Judicial review can mitigate several of the problems that plague the market for regulators’ reputation: it can provide the public with information on regulatory decision-making to which they were not privy; level the playing field between public-interest groups and narrow-interest groups; and reset the media agenda, facilitating coverage of meaningful issues.

At the most basic level, judicial review helps mitigating the asymmetric information problem. Nowhere is this more evident than with reason-giving requirements. These requirements force regulators to reveal what exactly they decided, and why they decided that way. Indeed, judicial review has become “the principal tool for prompting agencies to undertake reason-giving.”29 Courts shifted over the years from merely requiring regulators to provide reasons for the record, to giving the provided reasons a hard look: digging into whether the reasons are adequate, whether the methods used to acquire evidence are reliable, whether agencies dully considered all contrary evidence, and so on.30 As a byproduct, the public gets an expert opinion on whether regulators are doing their job properly.31

The existing literature emphasizes three types of justifications for reason-giving requirements:32 (1) bolstering “the legitimacy of government action”; (2) facilitating legal review of the decision after the fact; and (3) promoting internal reflection by the decision maker before the fact. We can now add another, nonexclusive, justification: (4) reason giving facilitates bottom-up, reputational monitoring of regulators.

By making regulators publicize their reasoning in detail, courts make it easier for civic society to assess, debate, and hold regulators accountable.33 A good example comes from judicial review of national security decisions. There, the court forced regulators to spell out in public the criteria for when and how they decide to transfer detainees to other countries, or target US citizens overseas.— Court-imposed disclosure made these decisions explicit and accessible, providing “a baseline against which ... the public may evaluate future executive behavior and challenge that behavior when it appears to countermand the stated policy.”—

Judicial review also mitigates the asymmetric monitoring problem. That is, judicial review allows public-interest groups to more readily mobilize the masses against bad regulation. Public-interest groups can more easily spot damning information about regulatory behavior through the litigation process, than they can through the political process.36 As one staff attorney in an environmentalist NGO told me: “so much of what the EPA does is opaque. So, even though [you can see that the] outcomes favor industry, the process of the EPA looks reasonable. Only litigation can pull out [and help you identify] the unreasonable aspects of regulator behavior.”37 Further, if a regulator ignores input from public-interest groups during the political process, the court will force her to explain why she did so after the fact.38

In that way, judicial review makes the regulator’s favoritism more visible. The increased visibility, in turn, makes it easier for public-interest groups to enlist the help of donors, volunteers, and citizens who are normally disengaged. We have seen this story in previous chapters, in the commercial context: litigation does not just reveal new information, but also increases the saliency and shapes the framing of existing pieces of information. As one commentator noted in the context of judicial review of school segregation policies: “The courts have helped politicize issues that otherwise might have remained unattended.”39

To appreciate the reputational impact of judicial review, we can follow the path of previous chapters, and look at how litigation shapes media coverage of regulators. Judicial review provides journalists information subsidies, as in ready-made versions of why the regulator took a certain decision, or detailed assessments of how that decision should affect the readers. Judicial review thereby reduces the costs for journalists of covering bad aspects of regulators’ behavior. It puts hitherto-ignored regulatory issues on the media and public agendas.

To illustrate, consider the 1995 Pulitzer-winning story of disability pension abuse by the Long Island police. There, the abuse of disability pension benefits has been going on for decades, while the political establishment was “unwilling to clash with the well-organized and well-financed police-union lobby, which pushes for more generous policy benefits while helping to finance politicians’ campaigns and delivering coveted endorsements.”— To use a famous political economy typology, the problem was of the concentrated-benefits, dispersed-costs kind:41 A powerful interest group enjoyed benefits at the expense of taxpayers. Those with the power to monitor and stop the abuse had no interest in fighting the powerful group on an issue that is far from the public’s eye. As an insider later confessed: “I think the big problem with the system is there’s not always someone on the other side.”— Then, investigative reporters from Newsday exposed the abuse, and their story reverberated. The increased saliency immediately pushed the regulators to step up and stop the abuse.

The most important part in this story, at least from our perspective, is what facilitated the journalistic exposé. The Newsday reporters could not have generated such an impactful story without having access to information form litigation. They culled court documents from tort litigation involving the supposed victims, showing that they were undeserving of the benefits they extracted. The causal chain worked thusly: litigation produces (as a byproduct) information on a neglected regulatory issue; the media picks up the information, packages it compellingly, and diffuses it widely, thereby putting the issue on the public agenda; and regulators react to the potential public backlash by taking care of the hitherto-neglected problem. “Where the public is ignorant of certain conditions, and political elites do not want to deal with them” the litigation process can change the political agenda, prioritizing hitherto unattended topics.—

Beyond increasing the saliency of a given issue, judicial review can also reduce the complexity of the issue at hand. As Emily Hammond Meazell suggested in the context of regulatory scientific determinations, a key function of judicial review is translating highly specialized information into a generalist account that even nonprofessionals can follow.— Judicial review thereby makes a complex issue more understandable and coverable by the media. Political scientists have long recognized that regulatory enforcement tends to drift away from the public interest in issues with low saliency and high complexity.45 When courts increase the saliency and reduce the complexity, they therefore reduce the risk of regulatory capture.

6.3.2 Refining the Basic Story: Limitations

Thus far, we have kept the story neat: public litigation produces information on how regulators behave, and the information translates into reputational pressures that push regulators to behave better. Yet in reality, the reputation-through-litigation dynamics are limited in the public litigation arena much more than they are in private litigation. This section elaborates on the unique limitations of public litigation, and then points to alternative channels, such as torts against the government.

Several of the limitations we covered in earlier chapters, in the context of corporate litigation, apply also here. Take for instance the time lag problem: If a regulator’s tenure is three years and the judicial process takes four years to get going, then the threat of reputation-through-litigation is not as deterring. Similarly, just like private litigation, there are types of biases that public litigation simply cannot fix, such as voters’ irrationality, or the media’s dependence on advertising dollars. We will not rehash the similar limitations here, but instead focus on three limitations that are unique to public law litigation: the ideological bent of judges, the ability of regulators to sidestep court-induced reputational pressures, and the ability of the industry to use court-induced reputational pressures as an influence mechanism.

First, the politicization of judicial review muddles the signal it sends. One well-established empirical pattern of judicial review is its ideological bent.— When judges decide whether to interfere with agency action, they are affected by their own personal political preferences. A conservative judge is more likely to vote down liberal agency actions, and vice versa.

The politicization of judicial review presents a challenge to our reputational argument, because politicization muddles the signal that litigation generates. If audiences observe a judge criticizing and overturning a regulator’s decision, they would not necessarily view it as indicative of the regulator being incompetent or captured. They could instead attribute the criticism to the judge’s own political preferences. Perhaps the regulator was promoting what she believes is the public interest, and it just happens to be the opposite of what the judge believes the public interest is. Private litigation can facilitate reputational control even when judges are biased, simply because the main impact comes from the process itself rather than the final verdict. In other words, the process of (private) litigation tends to generate relative objective documentation, regardless of the judge’s subjectively tilted interpretations. Yet public litigants do not enjoy the same information-extracting powers.

A second problem with reputation-through-publzc-litigation is that regulators may respond only symbolically or too aggressively. The BRT literature has established that regulators proactively manage their reputation. It is therefore safe to assume that when faced with court-generated reputational pressures, regulators will not stand idle but rather attempt to dilute the expected reputational sanction. Regulators may choose courses of action that are less likely to be reviewed in court to begin with.47 In cases where they are nevertheless challenged in court, regulators may engage in damage control by responding in a symbolic manner, weathering the storm without making substantive changes.48

To illustrate, let us recast the example of criticism directed at the SEC in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis. You may recall from Chapter 4 that the SEC responded to the public backlash by announcing a change in policy, committing to demanding more admissions in future settlements. Initially, it seemed that the court-generated reputational pressures worked. Then evidence started surfacing, suggesting that the new policy did not substantively address the criticism. In other words, the professed change of policy could have very well quieted down the public outcry without meaningfully improving the actual outcomes of SEC enforcement.

At the same time, I do not wish to overstate the co-opting-reputational-pressures limitation. Even symbolic responses and “cheap talk” commitments may represent a step in the right direction. They “shape citizens’ expectations from government and expose bureaucracies to external scrutiny when their performance falls short of expectations.”49 To go back to our example: while it is true that the SEC can ramp up the number of admissions in small cases, we saw in Chapter 4 that its commitment to change has also generated meaningful admissions in several impactful cases.

Another possibility that may limit the positive reputational effects of litigation is that regulators will overreact to court-generated reputational pressures. The logic here is intuitive: once bad news breaks, media coverage tends to gravitate toward the sensational and negative, looking for a villain. Such coverage may push regulators to engage in overkill. A good illustration comes from the breast implants litigation. There, litigation had the media pointing fingers at the FDA, which reacted by banning breast implants altogether. Many critics suggested that the FDA’s decision, at the time, was bad science (based on one piece of unsubstantiated evidence that surfaced in litigation) and bad policy, driven by the regulator’s desire to appease raging media scrutiny and public opinion.—

Here as well, I do not wish to overstate the point. Yes, the risk of litigation-driven media coverage pushing regulators to overreact is real. But when all things are considered, it seems that instances where regulators over-regulate due to media scrutiny balance out with many cases where the watchdog did not bark, and regulators ended up under-regulating because the issue remained under the public’s radar. To go back to the breast implants example, litigation helped breaking a decade-plus cycle of regulatory inaction. Before litigation-driven pressures pushed the FDA to err on the side of aggressively regulating breast implants, the FDA had been erring for more than a decade on the side of regulating too laxly, not pushing the industry to test the safety of their products as required.—

Finally, another problem with reputation-through-^u^lic-litigation is that the regulated industry itself often uses litigation as a lever. Challenging regulatory action in courts requires resources: time, money, and expertise. Special interest groups usually have more of these resources, and are therefore better at employing the judicial review channel in their favor, relative to the dispersed public.— Applied here, one could argue that court-generated reputational pressures are simply another mechanism used by special interest to capture regulators. A part of the problem, rather than the solution. To recast the tobacco litigation example: there, the industry sued the EPA, arguing that the regulator relied on junk science and became too trigger-happy.— A recent (rare) empirical study of the reputational effects of judicial review indeed focuses on how the regulated industry in Spain and in the UK uses legal challenges as a strategic resource, to gain favorable policies.54

The main premise of this argument is valid: the regulated industry is, indeed, likely to try to use judicial review as a lever. But it does not follow that our point is mute: judicial review will, nevertheless, generate positive reputational momentum. To understand why, consider another stylized fact from the BRT literature: it is better for regulators’ reputation to be perceived as over-regulating, than to be perceived as under-regulating. Once a certain regulatory issue becomes salient, the regulators will be less worried about appearing to be populists on the issue (over-regulating), and more worried about appearing to be in the industry’s pocket (under-regulating). Applied here, we can assume that the reputational vector generated by industry-driven judicial review would be weaker than the reputational vector generated by public-interest-group-driven judicial review.

6.3.3 Torts against the Government

Torts against the government are another type of litigation that produces quality information on regulators’ behavior, and actually avoids some of the abovementioned limitations of administrative litigation. A good starting point to illustrate would be Daryl Levinson’s skepticism regarding constitutional torts.55 Levinson maintains that deterrence does not work in tort claims against the government, because those who ultimately pay damages are us taxpayers, rather than the negligent regulators themselves. What Levinson misses is that making someone pay legal sanctions out of pocket is not the only way to deter. Litigation can deter regulators also by making them suffer nonlegal sanctions. Myriam Gilles’s account of the information-producing function of municipal liability suits provides a case in point, and maps nicely into our argument here.56 Constitutional tort victims wishing to hold municipalities liable cannot rely on vicarious liability, but rather have to show a consistent policy or custom, Gilles shows.57 As a result, constitutional tort victims usually try to unearth evidence of deliberate indifference, repeat offending, or a general problematic attitude on part of the municipal police force. This is exactly the type of information that is relevant to reputation judgments: it speaks to the intentionality and preventability of past behavior and is indicative of future behavior. Such claims are also likely to attract media attention, as they typically implicate high-profile social issues such as police brutality or government cover-ups.58

In all, if we map Gilles’s analysis of municipal liability suits onto Chapter 1’s analysis of how information translates into reputation, we can conclude that torts against the government often increase the likelihood that information will be properly attributed and widely diffused, thereby increasing the effectiveness of reputational deterrence.

*

The main gist of the reputation-through-litigation argument applies in public litigation as well. At the same time, the reputational dynamics seem to be less powerful here, compared to private litigation. Reason-giving requirements hold the promise of increasing the saliency and reducing the complexity of certain regulatory issues. But the availability and scope of discovery is limited. When a public-interest group brings a record-review litigation, or attempts to compel the regulator to act, very little new information comes out. Another problem with administrative litigation is that it is often less attractive for journalists to cover. Not newsworthy enough, in their eyes. We saw in Chapter 2 that part of the reason that journalists troll court documents is that they can often find there the materials for a good story, in particular identifiable victims and villains. Record-review litigation, by comparison, is dull. As a result, the reputational effects frequently come not necessarily from administrative litigation, but from other channels. One such channel is the aforementioned torts against the government. Another is litigation between two private parties that indirectly implicates the regulator’s behavior.

6.4 How Private Litigation Impacts Regulators' Reputation

It is intuitive to think that judicial review of regulatory behavior would affect what we think about the regulator. Less intuitively, but sometimes more importantly, even litigation between two private parties can affect regulators’ reputation. Section 6.4.1 sheds light on common scenarios in private litigation where the regulator’s behavior is implicated. Section 6.4.2 distinguishes between our reputation-through-litigation argument and the extant regulation-through-litigation literature.

6.4.1 The Basic Story

Litigation can make us reevaluate what we think about a regulator, even when the regulator is not a side to it. Think about a scenario of mass tort litigation between a polluting plant and victims who live in proximity to the plant. Such litigation may reveal information on how the defendant company skirted environmental regulation and got away with it. The litigation may thus affect not just the defendant company’s reputation, but also the regulator’s reputation, raising questions about how the regulator let the pollution happen under her not-so-watchful eye.—

To use a concreate example, consider the 2008 Pulitzer-winning project on faulty regulation of baby products.— There, the investigative journalists drew heavily from documents produced in litigation between victims of product defects and manufacturers of said products. Yet the journalists did not make it a story about a specific defected car seat or harmed baby. They rather pieced together the evidence into a big-picture story about systematic failures in regulating baby products, pointing fingers at the “captive,” “myopic,” and “docile” Consumer Product Safety Commission (CSPC). The private lawsuits therefore helped implicating the CSPC’s reputation, without the CSPC being a side in litigation. Following the journalistic exposé and ensuing public backlash, the CSPC changed its ways and acted more aggressively, as in making more sweeping recall demands. The reputational pressure seemingly worked. Another example comes from the tobacco litigation. There, the judge’s 1,742-page verdict was a “ringing denunciation” of the defendant tobacco companies.61 More pertinently, however, is that press coverage of the verdict did not stop at criticizing the tobacco companies, but pointed fingers at the regulators, for not having enough gumption to rein in the powerful industry.62

The mechanisms through which private litigation typically affects regulators’ reputation differ from the ones we highlighted in the previous section, when discussing judicial review. Unlike judicial review, judges presiding over private litigation would not require the regulator to provide detailed reasoning, or directly evaluate the adequacy of regulators’ reasoning. Yet in private litigation the parties themselves have strong incentives to use their fact-finding powers to extract information that indirectly implicates regulators’ behavior.

To illustrate, consider the frequent usage of two tort law doctrines, namely, regulatory compliance defense and negligence per se. Defendants are the ones raising the regulatory compliance defense, arguing that their behavior cannot be negligent if they complied with existing statutory/regulatory standards; or that their product cannot be defective if it meets the relevant regulatory requirements.— Yet the law treats regulatory compliance only as a partial defense. It is therefore not enough for defendants to show evidence of their compliance with the standard; they also have to convince the court that the standard is worthy. In other words, the regulatory compliance defense “rests on a factual presumption regarding the regulatory process.”64 In deciding whether to accept the defense, courts would typically evaluate the regulatory process: how deliberative, fair, thorough, and sound it was; whether the regulators have been updating the standard to keep with evolving knowledge of the risk in question; and so on.65 It is not hard to envision such private litigation turning into a referendum on how competent and public serving the regulator has been.

There is a broader point at play here, about the complementarities between regulation and litigation. Many commentators have called on courts to adopt a stronger version of the regulatory compliance defense.66 These commentators usually invoke an institutional competence argument: regulators develop expertise, and so generalist courts should defer to them more.67 Yet the proponents of stronger regulatory compliance defense miss a crucial aspect, namely, information problems. Regulators often rely on information from the regulated industry itself when setting standards ex ante.68 As a result, regulators may set the standards suboptimally to begin with, and fail to update it over time when a more stringent standard is called for. Remember the regulating rates of return example: the regulator depends on the industry to trigger an update, yet the industry has no incentives to trigger an update that makes things worse for them. Litigation serves a key function here: extracting valuable information on whether the standard is adequate or needs updating. Once the information surfaces, regulators may be compelled to protect their reputation by updating the standard. And the mere background threat of litigation deters regulators ex ante.

While the regulatory compliance defense often implicates the regulator’s standard-setting prowess, the negligence per se doctrine typically implicates the regulator’s enforcement efforts. Plaintiffs are the ones raising the negligence per se claim: if you manage to show that defendants routinely skirted regulation, you can establish negligence.69 The prospect of securingpunitive damages especially incentivizes plaintiffs to not limit themselves to bringing evidence about the particular harm done to them, but rather produce evidence on defendant misconduct more broadly, such as showing how defendants have been suppressing information on adverse health effects.70 When the media follows up on such evidence, they often do not limit themselves to the “big bad polluting company” framing, but also adopt a “regulators were asleep at the helm!” angle, suggesting to their readers that a lax regulatory enforcement let the industry off the hook.—

6.4.2 Refining the Basic Story: Information Production vs. Reputation-Shaping

I am hardly the first one that argues that private litigation can lead to changes in regulation. A sizable literature - grouped together for our purposes under the “regulation through litigation” moniker - looks at how litigation is not only about settling past disputes, but also about bringing sweeping changes to defendants’ future behavior.72 The main difference between my argument and that literature lies in the mechanism of influence. Each account answers the “how litigation brings about societal change” question differently. The extant accounts suggest that policy changes come from judicial rulings, directly: judges are acting as de facto legislators/regulators, filling gaps in statutory frameworks, and forcing defendant companies to accept new regulations outside the normal political process.73 I, by contrast, suggest that the process of litigation propels the regulators to act on their own, because it threatens their reputations.

If private litigation indeed influences regulation only indirectly, it takes the sting away from the most common criticism of regulatory litigation, namely, the criticism of unaccountability. Many scholars have used the “regulation through litigation” moniker in a negative connotation, claiming that unaccountable judges and plaintiffs’ lawyers make broad societal changes without input from the public.74 Yet if the main effect of litigation is reputational, then input from the public plays a key role. When litigation generates information and raises public awareness to regulatory behavior, it arguably increases public accountability and facilitates meaningful participation.

In that regard, my account of private litigation is closest to Wendy Wagner’s version, which emphasizes the information-extracting qualities of litigation.75 Litigation helps regulators regulate better, Wagner claims, by providing them information. Litigation unlocks “stubborn information”: information that regulators have a hard time extracting from the regulated industry on their own.76 Normally, the regulated industry can use their superior access to information and expertise, as well as other influence tactics, to keep crucial information away from regulators. Litigation disrupts these dynamics: when regulated companies face resourceful plaintiff lawyers armed with court junctions, they reluctantly provide the needed information.

Where my argument differs from Wagner’s is in the difference between producing information and affecting reputations. In my version, litigation propels regulators to act not solely by surfacing information, but also by facilitating wide diffusion (typically through media coverage) and proper attribution (making sure the regulator’s overseers understand the regulator’s role in the debacle) of that information.

The BRT literature teaches us that to it is not so much the availability, but rather the visibility of information that propels regulators to act.77 Producing new information is therefore neither a necessary nor a sufficient condition for litigation to bring about regulatory changes.78 A deeper look at many paradigmatic examples of regulatory litigation reveals that the regulators already enjoyed access to the information in question, or could have easily accessed it.79 To borrow Wagner’s term, the information in question in these cases was hardly “stubborn.” The real impact of litigation came not from producing new information but rather from lighting a fire underneath the regulators’ feet. I observed similar dynamics in my study of the 1995-2015 Pulitzer-winning investigations: more often than not, the problem was not that regulators could not access information, but rather that regulators were too reluctant to act against powerful players (and then started acting once the issue gained saliency).

In the clergy-sexual abuse scandal, for example, litigation made it “politically less costly” to take action against the powerful Catholic Church.— Along similar lines, Ida Tarbell’s muckraking project on the Standard Oil Company relied on information from law enforcement actions that was already available to the public, and certainly to regulators. Yet it was only after Tarbell published her stories that the attorney general mustered courage to break the monopoly.

Litigation brings about regulatory change when it manages to make the costs of regulatory failures obtrusive to the regulators’ overseers in the public and congress. It pushes an issue to the top of the media, public, and regulatory agendas.81 In communication scientists’ lingo, this is the difference between “framing” and “priming.”— Existing accounts of regulation through litigation focus on framing effects, suggesting that litigation shapes how a certain situation (e.g., the dangers of smoking) is presented to the public. I, by contrast, focus on priming effects, suggesting that litigation directs the public’s attention to certain attributes of the regulator, making us evaluate the regulator on the basis of these traits (e.g., not being diligent enough in demanding information from the tobacco industry).

6.5 Implications

Recognizing that judicial review affects regulators not just directly, by striking down their decisions, but also indirectly, by producing information that shapes their reputations, opens up space to reassessing the extant literature on judicial review and its policy implications. If litigation indeed generates information and affects the reputation of regulators, then the main thrust of the implications we have sketched in previous chapters, for doctrines of corporate and securities laws, apply also here, for doctrines of administrative and constitutional law. This section applies the reputational perspective to reevaluate longstanding debates over the hard look doctrine, standing limitations, confidential settlements, and judicial activism.

6.5.1 Standards of Review

The extent literature on judicial review endlessly debates whether courts should interfere with regulators’ decisions. One camp argues that judges interfere too much. Nonelected, generalist judges should not interfere with the decisions of elected and professional regulators, or so the argument goes.83 Yet, if judicial review can make public officials change their behavior not necessarily by striking down their decisions, but rather by making them face public pressure, then judicial review arguably makes the political system more representative of citizens’ preferences.84

The other camp argues that judges defer too much. Courts employ abstention doctrines and rarely intervene in regulatory decisions. Further, in the rare events where courts do not abstain, they limit their review to the process, rather than the merits, of the decision in question.85 Yet from an information-production perspective, it matters less if courts ultimately decide to defer to the regulator’s judgment, as long as theprocess of litigation flushes out information about how the regulators behaved.

Abstention doctrines and lax standards of review would hurt information production only to the extent that they serve as pleading hurdles of sorts, killing any challenge in its infancy (or discouraging public-interest groups from filing in court ex ante). If, on the other hand, Justice Scalia was right in saying that deference does not mean “anything more than considering [the views of the other branches] with attentiveness and profound respect” before the court rejects them, then there is little reason to worry about information production.86 In other words, we should not evaluate the effectiveness of judicial review merely through the legal bottom line. Much like with in discussion of corporate law litigation and the deferential business judgment rule, the legal outcomes of administrative litigation may skew toward respondents, yet the process itself can shed light on how problematic respondents’ behavior has been, thereby propelling them to change their behavior ex ante.—

To illustrate, consider the extensive debate over the hard look doctrine.— Several scholars have suggested that the hard look doctrine must be inconsequential, not guiding actual judicial review, because the empirical evidence shows that agencies enjoy a very high win rate in courts.— Scholars also point out that regardless of the standard that courts apply (e.g., Chevron90 vs. Skidmore),— agencies’ win rates remain roughly the same.92 Yet to fully evaluate the hard look doctrine, we cannot limit ourselves to the “legal” results of cases (i.e., how courts decide, as illustrated by agencies’ win rates). We also need to take into account the ultimate results, that is, how regulators changed their behavior following litigation. The hard look doctrine affects the quantity and quality of information production during litigation. A regulator that needs to explain herself to the court under the hard look doctrine will have to produce granular information on what, why, and how she decided. And courts are more likely, under the hard look doctrine, to provide a detailed, relatively accessible account on how the regulator behaved. In other words, to evaluate the hard look doctrine we cannot satisfy ourselves with evidence about who wins in court; we rather need to look at how media coverage of the regulatory issue changed during and after litigation, and how the regulator reacted. The doctrine may not matter much for the legal results, but it matters for the reputational results.

A concrete example comes from our Chapter 4 story of judicial review of the SEC. After Judge Rakoff started raising questions vocally, the SEC settlement practices had become the center of national attention. The SEC had eventually won the legal battle, as the Second Circuit Court of Appeals has reemphasized the need to defer to the regulators’ discretion. Yet by then the SEC had already lost the battle in the court of public opinion, and had to react by publicly changing their enforcement policies to require more admissions going forward.

6.5.2 Standing and Redressability

If courts indeed affect the reputational pressures that operate on regulators, then access to courts dictates the vector of such reputational pressures. To fulfill its potential and combat the asymmetries in monitoring abilities, access to court itself has to be symmetric - available to public-interest groups as it is to special-interest groups. Yet in reality, even after the 1970s wave of liberalizing standing requirements,— there remain great asymmetries: the regulated industry establishes standing much easier than the supposed beneficiaries of regulation (the public, via public-interest groups) do. First, there is the “injury-in-fact” requirement: courts normally do not allow standings in issues of wide grievance, insisting that the plaintiff shows that she was specifically injured.— Then, there is the “redressability” requirement: plaintiffs have to show that the remedies they seek are capable of redressing the supposed harms.—

The one-two punch of injury in fact and redressability has significantly limited the ability of public-interest groups to challenge in courts - and thereby draw attention to - certain types of regulatory misbehavior.— While I am hardly the first to point out the asymmetries in standing between special-interest- and public-interest groups,97 the reputational angle does add a new twist to the debate: spotlighting an underappreciated benefit of symmetric access to courts. Access to courts leads to access to the media agenda. And access to media agenda leads to influence on regulatory agenda.

This is more than just a semantic exercise. Recognizing the links between judicial review to media agenda, and between media agenda to regulatory behavior, has implications for how courts should apply the redressability requirement. When evaluating redressability, courts inevitably engage in some kind of forecasting: deciphering whether the remedies sought can redress the harm. Recognizing that judicial review generates reputational pressures should affect the forecasting. Even in cases where judicial review is not likely to provide compensation to a specific past injury, it may nevertheless generate reputational pressures that will deter future harms. Pertinently, court-induced reputational pressures are likely to reduce the probabilities of future harms to the group that the plaintiffs represent.—

6.5.3 Confidential Settlements

We saw that an important channel of reputation-relevant information on regulators are torts against the government. This type of litigation escapes many of the limitations of administrative litigation: it features more extensive discovery and is relatively immune to politicization of judges; it comes with strong monetary incentives for plaintiffs and their lawyers to extract damning information; and so on. Yet torts against the government have one problematic feature, namely, the tendency of parties to the dispute to agree to keep the information exchanged during litigation confidential, in exchange for higher/earlier settlements. Chapter 7 will elaborate on the divergence between private and public incentives: both parties have incentives to agree to confidentiality, while the public interest would benefit from openness. The same dynamics may apply even more strongly in the context of torts against the government, due to the agency problem: taxpayers who are not privy to litigation are the ones paying for settlements, while the defendant regulators are the ones enjoying the benefits of confidentiality.— The upshot is that we should consider imposing limitations on the ability of regulators to settle, and to settle confidentially. Such limitations already exist in certain regulatory areas in the United States and elsewhere in the world,100 and we should aim to expand that blueprint.

6.5.4 The Role of Judicial Review in Mitigating Regulatory Capture

The final implication is the most general one: applying the reputational perspective to reassess the debate over the proper role of judicial review in mitigating regulatory capture. Proponents of judicial review claim that it is an important check on regulatory capture.101 By adding another veto point, judicial review increases the costs of capturing the system, or so the argument goes.102 And it is an especially effective veto point, proponents claim: judges enjoy tenure and so are less amenable to capture by career concerns, and are, in general, more neutral and less politically involved.103 Other scholars dismiss this optimistic account. They emphasize how only a subset of regulatory behaviors are reviewable, as courts tend to avoid second-guessing regulatory decisions.104

To judge which claim is more convincing, we need to make some assumptions about what drives regulators. If, as in traditional public choice theory, you believe that regulators mostly maximize their narrow self-interest, then you have to acknowledge that there is little that judicial review can do. Judges may invalidate specific captured regulatory decisions after the fact, but they cannot overcome the inherent advantages that special interests enjoy in the way of offering lucrative future business opportunities or campaign financing. Judicial review is limited in dealing with the basic incentive problems that public choice highlights, for various reasons. Special-interest groups employ their better resources to use the judicial review channel in their favor. The same veto point meant to fight off attempts to capture the system, is in reality often used to fight off and delay public-interest reforms.105

If, on the other hand, you think that regulators care about reputation and that judicial review may affect regulators’ reputation, then you are more likely to view judicial review as part of the solution to regulatory capture. We can couch the argument similarly to how we did in the corporate context: it is well accepted that media scrutiny, when done effectively, is a great antidote to regulatory capture.106 Now the question becomes what determines the effectiveness of media scrutiny. If one recognizes that judicial review can increase the saliency and reduce the complexity of a given regulatory issue, then the evidence we discussed in Chapter 2 suggests that such judicial review would greatly increase the effectiveness of media scrutiny of said issue. Once an issue gains saliency, and becomes more understandable and coverable by the media, the threat of public backlash reverses the special-interest group politics dynamics. Judicial review can therefore have a salutary effect on regulatory behavior in ways that were hitherto underappreciated.

Viewing judicial review from such reputational perspective provides some clues as to when courts should be more or less active when reviewing regulators’ decisions: the key is in saliency and complexity. Judicial review would be most desirable in cases where the costs and benefits of regulation are less salient to the public.107

6.6 Final Thoughts: Public Litigation's Relative Impact on Reputation

We saw throughout this chapter that the reputation-through-litigation argument works differently in public litigation than it does in private litigation. Part of the difference is due to legal doctrines, such as lack of far-reaching discovery in public litigation. Another part of the difference is due to the alternatives - the non-litigation sources of information in play. Litigation is not the only channel through which the legal system shapes regulators’ reputation. Nonjudicial channels, such as freedom of information (FOI) requests or congressional oversight hearings, also play a role.

FOI is not available for private entities but is in play for public entities, facilitating bottom-up monitoring of regulators. The more the media and the public can rely on non-litigation information, the less the (relative) reputational impact of litigation would be. Indeed, this difference between public and private litigation came up in each method I used in my “law-as-source” study detailed in Chapter 2. The investigative reporters I interviewed frequently cited the ability to rely on FOI laws as one reason for why it is relatively easier to hold big government to account than to hold big business to account. The reporters’ tip sheets on how to scrutinize the government make less frequent references to court documents than tip sheets on how to scrutinize private businesses. And the content analysis of prizewinning investigative projects reveals a recurring theme: a journalist submitting a FOI request to extract information from regulators, and then using it to show her readers how the regulator has been sitting on the information without acting on it.

To illustrate, consider the 2015 Pulitzer-winning story on healthcare providers milking Medicare at the expense of taxpayers. Wall Street Journal reporters submitted FOIA requests that forced to government to release Medicare data kept secret for decades. The reporters then sifted through the data and packaged it into a compelling story, showing for example how doctors are routinely testing the elderly for drugs such as heroin and “angel dust.” The reporters also made the costs of Medicare abuse clear, indicating that taxpayers are on the hook for nearly $60 billion on bogus payments each year.— The JournaPs story ignited a public outcry. And the public outcry propelled regulators to act: the relevant federal agency started denying industry’s requests to cover even more questionable tests, the FBI started investigating medical providers who collected alarmingly high amounts of Medicare money, and so on.109 Note how this newfound regulatory action was due not to new information but rather to increased saliency: the Journal's FOIA request simply surfaced (and highlighted, and widely diffused) data that was available to regulators but kept secret from the public since 1979.

Yet another channel that implicates regulators’ reputation is nonjudicial reviews. Think for example about the regulation czar - the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA) - reviewing the work of a specific regulator, or of a congressional oversight hearing where the regulator is “grilled.”— Here as well, the list of Pulitzer-winning investigations provides cases in point. In 2003, the New York Times exposed the abuse of the mentally ill in state-regulated homes. The Times" reporter culled more than 5,000 pages of annual state inspection records, using them to draw attention to longstanding disorder in state-run homes.111 The reporting prompted a class-action lawsuit, which later translated into New York State’s Department of Health gradually moving many of the mentally ill residents to better locations and treatment.— Again it was not new information but rather the journalistic spotlight that propelled action: the state itself had been issuing damning reports for decades, but chose to ignore them.

Similar dynamics were in play a year earlier, with the 2002 Pulitzer-winning investigation of neglect of kids in foster homes. There, the Washington Post obtained records of a Child Fatality Review Committee. The Committee consistently detailed the neglect and deaths of many kids put in protective care, yet its conclusions were heard only in closed-doors government meetings, and its recommendations were constantly buried.— Once the Post journalists spotlighted and packaged the data into a compelling story, the regulator stepped in, overhauling the child welfare system.

On paper, then, FOIA and nonjudicial reviews should provide ample information for journalists to hold regulators to account. Yet as Chapter 2 alluded to, these channels are too often lacking. The implementation of FOIA is dysfunctional, fraught with delays and denials. And congress convenes special hearings usually only on issues that already gained saliency. Congressional hearings normally do not spotlight an ignored issue - they amplify an issue that has already reached the spotlight.

The upshot is that while non-litigation channels play a more prominent role in holding regulators to account (relative to holding businesses to account), they still cannot fully substitute litigation-generated reputational pressures. In the regulatory arena, much like in the business arena, litigation is needed to supplement the information environment and facilitate reputational control.

A promising venue for future research would be identifying the regulatory areas in which litigation plays a bigger/smaller role in inducing reputational pressures. In some areas, the market for regulators’ reputation works fine even without litigation. Think for example of regulatory areas where the feedback is immediate and clear, as in when under-regulation brings about catastrophes that cause acute identifiable harms to victims. In other regulatory areas, reputational concerns would not work without litigation. Think about areas where the harms are more latent, opaque, and disperse, as in toxic pollution that increases the probability of future latent diseases. In these areas, the implications we noted earlier (such as the case against confidential settlements, or for liberal standing) apply more forcefully.

A N D P H A R M A C E U T I C A L R E G U L AT I O N AT T H E F D A 45 (2010). There are at least two related-yet-distinct notions of regulators’ reputation. One is the notion of regulators’ career concerns, which is oft-mentioned in the context of the “revolving doors” argument: regulators wish to maximize their future earning opportunities, and this desire affects their behavior while in the public sector. Such labor-market reputation notion is different from the one we use here, which speaks to how regulators seek the positive evaluations and esteem of various audiences, such as those who appoint them or are affected by them, beyond and regardless of future job opportunities. Another important distinction concerns the different effects of reputation at the level of the individual, and reputation at the level of the regulatory agency. We collapse this distinction for our purposes here, for considerations of scope. Brevity and scope also dictate that we lump together all types of regulators - political appointees, “lifer” bureaucrats, and so forth. In reality, reputational concerns operate differently on each type of regulator. But for our modest purposes here, namely, drawing attention to a hitherto-understudied channel of influence on regulators (information coming from the legal system), treating them as a group suffices.
