The Case against Mandatory Arbitration

8.1 Introduction

Throughout the 2010s, the Supreme Court of the United States has enforced contractual provisions that force arbitration of disputes and ban class actions.1 Unsurprisingly, companies quickly went on to instill these mandatory arbitration provisions in their contracts with consumers, employees, and suppliers.2 A heated debate ensued, bursting out of academic circles and into popular media, over the desirability of such mandatory arbitration revolution. Proponents argued it will improve efficiency, by streamlining dispute resolution and reducing lawyer fees. Opponents argued it will be unfair for the already disadvantaged workers, consumers, and suppliers, depriving them of their day in court. Yet the existing debate too often misses the forest for the trees. Instead of analyzing fairness and efficiency toward parties to a given dispute, we should focus on effects on the market overall. Even if shifting from litigation to arbitration would be good for a specific company and its consumers/workers/investors,3 such shift may prove detrimental to the market overall, because we would lose the positive externalities (in the form of quality information on corporate behavior) that come with litigation.

We saw in previous chapters that litigation facilitates market discipline. Litigation provides market players with information on corporate misconduct, thereby helping them avoid doing business with shady companies and businesspersons. But in a world where disputes are either diffused (because class action is banned) or funneled to behind-closed-doors arbitration, the flow of information is severally curtailed, and reputational deterrence loses its power.

To be sure, transforming our reputation-through-litigation argument into a case against mandatory arbitration is far from automatic. Before making the reputational case against mandatory arbitration, one needs to consider both the context and the counterfactual. In some areas, most of the law-as-source benefits come from direct channels such as FOIA or disclosure laws, rather than from litigation. In these contexts, moving away from litigation will not hurt reputational deterrence much. In other areas, FOIA or disclosure laws do not produce valuable information, but neither does litigation. Some types of litigation are simply not geared toward information production: think for example about certain doctrines that make plaintiffs less likely to survive the pleading stage and reach discovery.

And even if litigation in a given context does produce valuable information, we still need to consider the counterfactual: the possibility that, once we move away from litigation, other institutions would emerge to produce valuable information. For example, ramped-up public enforcement, or individual arbitration, may substitute the informational benefits we currently get from litigation, and at lower costs.

The reputational case against mandatory arbitration is therefore highly context-specific. Accordingly, this chapter evaluates the desirability of mandatory arbitration in a specific context: shareholder claims in corporate and securities laws. As of this writing, corporate and securities litigation remain the last bastion where class actions still reign. But commentators, practitioners, and policymakers have suggested that the mandatory arbitration revolution can, and should, apply to shareholder litigation as well.4 The idea is that companies could amend their charters or bylaws to include such a provision, or go public with it, thereby forcing shareholders to arbitrate their claims individually, putting an end to shareholder litigation as we have come to know it. By delving into the details of such proposal in the shareholder litigation context, we get to extract more generalizable lessons to other contexts as well.

Those in favor of market arbitration often base their argument on the notion that ending shareholder litigation as we came to know it is not a bad thing. They cite evidence on how shareholder litigation fares badly in compensating victims and amounts to little more than a transfer of wealth from investors to lawyers. Yet compensation is not the only measuring stick, or even the most important one. When evaluating a proposed shift from litigation to arbitration, we should also consider deterrence. The critical question is whether litigation has a salutary effect on corporate behavior. Litigation will have such a salutary effect whenever it makes defendants internalize the costs of their misbehavior. Importantly, litigation can make defendants behave better not just by threatening them with legal sanctions, but also indirectly, by threatening them with nonlegal sanctions. Litigation can exact (noninsurable) emotional costs. And it can facilitate reputational penalties: the risk of having damning information about how you behaved become public, thereby reducing the willingness of outside observers to trust and do business with you going forward. Allowing companies to force arbitration without class action in such a context would be a mistake.

The chapter proceeds in five sections. Section 8.2 maps the contours of the existing mandatory arbitration debate. Section 8.3 approaches the debate from a different angle, namely our reputation-through-litigation perspective. The section highlights how shareholder litigation, specifically, is more front-loaded than other types of litigation. The main event always comes early: think about the demand requirement in derivative actions or the pleading stage in securities class actions. As a result, plaintiffs in shareholder litigation find it harder to survive motions to dismiss and reach discovery. Yet, counterintuitively, that does not mean that shareholder litigation is less informative. Plaintiffs have developed prediscovery investigatory tools, such as requesting to inspect the company’s books and records or locating current or former employees willing to share damning information. These tools allow not just for better pleading but also for production of reputation-relevant information. Section 8.3 also breaks down the differential reputational impact of various types of shareholder litigation: derivate actions, securities class actions, and deal litigation.

Section 8.4 considers the counterfactual: in a world with mandatory arbitration of shareholder claims, could other institutions substitute litigation’s informational benefits? This section assesses the information-production potential of enforcement by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), individual arbitration by institutional investors, and standalone requests to inspect a company’s books and records, and finds them all wanting. SEC enforcement is geared toward maximizing enforcement numbers rather than information (as Chapter 4 showed). Individual arbitration is geared toward confidentiality rather than openness. And any information gleaned from requests to inspect the company’s books has to remain confidential unless it is filed in conjunction with litigation. The upshot is that a shift to arbitration is bound to result in loss of informational benefits.

Section 8.5 sketches policy implications. Recognizing the informational role of litigation puts a thumb on the scales against importing mandatory arbitration provisions to corporate and securities laws. If courts and regulators nevertheless decide to enforce such provisions, we should at a minimum set basic rules ensuring that shareholder arbitration would produce meaningful information. For example, we can mandate “explained awards,” whereby the arbitrator provides a short, publicly available factual description of what happened, as well as reasoning for her decision.

Section 8.6 offers concluding thoughts on the applicability of the reputational case against mandatory arbitration more generally, beyond the shareholder litigation context. The section uses specific examples from labor law, which illustrate how a shift to arbitration would have different effects on different markets. I then use examples spurred by the #MeToo movement to highlight the other side: instead of looking at how a shift to arbitration will affect reputation, looking at how reputational concerns affect firms’ decisions to adopt mandatory arbitration provisions to begin with.

8.2 The Existing Debate

Mandatory arbitration of shareholder claims is hardly a new topic. But the contours of the debate have recently changed. The existing literature has focused on whether arbitration provisions are consistent with state and federal laws.5 Historically, companies considering adopting such provisions had to anticipate facing opposition from the courts and, notably, the SEC. But the line of Supreme Court pro-arbitration decisions, coupled with the Trump administration pressuring the SEC to change its anti-arbitration stance, now signal to companies wishing to adopt such provisions that any remaining legal hurdles will be cleared.6 Section 8.2.1 elaborates.

Assuming the legal hurdles are cleared, should companies adopt arbitration provisions? Should the SEC give in to pressures and approve them? Section

  • 8.2.2 details the existing policy arguments. The extant debate evaluates the desirability of arbitration by reference to the benchmark - the current state of shareholder litigation. Proponents of the shift to arbitration suggest it will leave investors better off, simply because litigation currently offers them very little compensation with very high fees. Notably missing from the debate, however, is a full account of litigation’s deterrence benefits.

8.2.1 Is Mandatory Arbitration Good Law?

Historically, companies wishing to adopt mandatory arbitration provisions for shareholder claims anticipated facing a slew of legal hurdles. The SEC had steadfastly opposed such provisions, viewing them as a violation of the securities laws’ “anti-waiver” provisions.7 In 2012, for example, the SEC pressured private-equity giant Carlyle to drop a mandatory arbitration provision before it signed off on the company’s IPO plans and allowed companies to exclude from their proxy materials shareholder proposals to adopt such provisions.8

Getting courts to sign off on arbitration provisions was also far from given. The Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) enforces arbitration provisions among contractual parties. It was not clear whether corporate governance documents would be considered contracts for FAA purposes, if only because they lack the key feature of bargaining between arm’s-length counterparties.9 A more recent challenge came in 2015, when the Delaware legislature amended its corporate law to allow forum-exclusion bylaws only if they do not exclude Delaware’s courts.10 A sweeping arbitration provision would run against such law.

In recent years, however, the legal hurdles started clearing. In 2011, the Supreme Court handed down its AT&TMobility LLC v. Concepcion— decision, enforcing an arbitration provision with a class action waiver, while ruling that the FAA trumps state contract law. Contract law, like corporate law, is considered the domain of the states, but that did not stop the Court.12 Then in 2013, the American Express Co. v. Italian Colors Restaurant— decision upheld Concepcion and further expanded the FAA’s scope by enforcing the arbitration clause even when it renders a federal law (the Sherman Act) ineffective. In both decisions the issue of consent seems to take a backseat to a more policy-oriented approach. Consumers of cell phone plans cannot bargain their way out of take-it-or-leave-it arbitration provisions, yet the Court enforced these provisions on them, suggesting that arbitration is the more effective procedure to handle their disputes.

The Concepcion and Italian Colors Restaurant decisions did more than just signal the lowering of legal hurdles. They also significantly increased the benefits of fighting any remaining legal uncertainties for companies; the real innovation was not in respecting arbitration provisions, but rather in enforcing the class action waivers in these provisions.14

A similar pro-arbitration turn may be taking place inside the SEC, with nudges from the Trump administration.— In 2017, the US Treasury prepared a report (in response to Executive Order 13,772) on how to relax regulations that stymie activity in capital markets.16 The Treasury report identified reducing the costs of litigation as a key step toward reinvigorating US stock listings and recommended that the SEC investigate a shift to arbitration. The media has since reported that the Trump administration keeps pushing the SEC to reverse its anti-arbitration stance and that the SEC now privately signals to companies its willingness to change course.17 In July 2017, then-SEC Commissioner Michael Piwowar floated the idea in a public speech18: “For shareholder lawsuits, companies can come to us to ask for relief to put in mandatory arbitration into their charter ... I would encourage companies to come and talk to us about that.”19

Given this evident pro-arbitration bent, mandatory arbitration provisions are now much more likely to be considered consistent with state and federal laws. Why have we yet to see companies rushing to adopt them? We can conjecture that there is a first-mover disadvantage that companies fear. The first company that adopts such a provision will expose itself to the costs associated with defending its stance in the courtroom and the court of public opinion.—

However, once the first test case proves successful, there is reason to expect many other companies to follow.— Is that a good thing?

8.2.2 Is Mandatory Arbitration Good Policy?

Those in favor of shifting to mandatory arbitration usually make their case by criticizing the existing state of shareholder litigation. Shareholder litigation has two main rationales: compensation and deterrence.22 By now there is wide agreement that shareholder litigation fares badly on the first prong: compensation.23 The recoveries that shareholder plaintiffs get are nominal.24 And in the rare cases where compensation is not nominal, critiques continue, it is circular.25 That is, because the company itself (directly or through insurance) is the one often compensating the plaintiffs, the costs are borne by the company’s existing shareholders. Diversified investors are therefore as likely to receive payment as plaintiffs, as they are to pay as defendants. Once you factor in the transaction costs of litigation (notably, lawyers’ fees), many scholars conclude that shareholder litigation merely transfers wealth from investors to lawyers.26 Against this background, mandatory-arbitration proponents claim that a shift to arbitration will actually improve things for consumers/investors. Arbitration will generate higher monetary reliefs with lower transaction costs (a quicker, more cost-effective procedure).

A glaring weakness in the existing arguments for arbitration and against litigation is the lack of attention to the other social goal of litigation, namely, deterrence.27 This is a broader issue: most empirical work on shareholder litigation focuses on compensation, leaving deterrence understudied.28 In the arbitration versus litigation debate, those favoring arbitration bypass the lack of evidence by assuming that little compensation translates into weak deterrence.29 A perfect illustration comes from the abovementioned Treasury report: the report mentions the possibility that securities class actions contribute to deterrence, only to quickly dismiss it by invoking the low-and-circular compensation point,

and then calls for considering a shift to arbitration.30 While it is understandable that difficulties in measuring deterrence make it much less amenable to empirical work, deterrence is simply too important to be ignored or lumped together with compensation.31

Deterrence does not hinge solely on compensation. Litigation can impose costs on defendants - making them internalize the social costs of their misconduct - even without compensating plaintiffs. Pertinently, litigation can expose defendants to nonlegal (and uninsurable) sanctions. It can impose emotional costs on defendants.32 And it can hurt their reputations. In other words, when assessing deterrence, we need to consider both direct- and indirect-deterrence effects of facilitating nonlegal sanctions.

The existing arguments against mandatory arbitration tend to ignore the indirect-deterrence angle. One common type of criticism emphasizes the adverse effects of arbitration on plaintiffs in specific disputes. The arbitration procedure is tilted in favor of defendants, who get to pick their favorite arbitrators and curtail discovery, the argument goes.33 Shifting to arbitration may result in more meritorious claims getting barred to begin with or in a transfer from small to large shareholders.34 These criticisms are mostly generic and well debated, and I have little to add.

This book raises another type of concern, namely, the adverse effects of arbitration on third parties. There exist ample accounts that highlight the positive externalities of litigation that will be lost if we shift to mandatory arbitration. Yet most of these arguments emphasize “legal” externalities. That is, they claim that litigation cultivates a vibrant, constantly evolving law that can instruct corporate behavior.35 This book spotlights a different version of positive externalities: nonlegal externalities. Litigation, in our version, does not just help potential defendants plan ahead and avoid legal landmines; it does not just help regulators prioritize better; it also helps market players - consumers, suppliers, and investors - make better decisions regarding with whom to keep doing business.36 The next section elaborates.

8.3 How Shifting to Arbitration Affects the Market for Reputation

Applying the reputational framework to the issue of mandatory arbitration is not automatic, and requires context-specific examination. This section hones in on the context: we start by asking to what extent does media scrutiny matter for corporate governance issues? If it matters greatly, to what extent does shareholder litigation affect said media scrutiny? How does specific doctrines of corporate and securities laws affect information production in litigation? And how do specific types of shareholder litigation differ from each other in terms of information production?

8.3.1 Media Scrutiny Matters for Corporate Governance

Commercial legal scholars have traditionally understudied issues of how information is diffused, and what role the media plays in corporate governance.37 Yet a nascent-but-burgeoning literature in other fields keeps producing evidence on the effects of agenda-setting, framing, and diffusion by the media. That literature highlights just how significant the role of the media is.

Communication scholars categorize the media’s impact into capital-markets effects and corporate-governance effects.38 Within the former category, financial economists have shown that the scope and tone of media coverage moves stock market prices even when the media reports contain no new information. One classic study found that a front-page New York Times article about a biotech company caused the stock prices to skyrocket, even though the article contained no new information and was actually repeating information that the Times had previously published in a back-page story.39 More broadly, the intensity of media coverage was found to be conducive to the quality of financial markets.—

Within the latter category - corporate-governance effects - studies find that media scrutiny increases the responsiveness of corporate decision makers to shareholders,41 as well as to salient outside groups, such as environmentalists.42 Survey-based evidence shows that top managers view negative media coverage as the biggest threat to corporate reputation.43 Pertinently, a recent study found that media coverage of corporate misconduct creates financial risk: one negative article brings with it an increase in credit risk in the magnitude of about $1.3 million in additional servicing of debt.44 In fact, the law itself acknowledges the key role of the media in disciplining corporate behavior. The doctrine developed in Caremark, for example, treats prior media coverage as a red flag that should propel directors to act or indicate that their internai monitoring channels were not functioning.—

Once we recognize the salutary effect of media scrutiny on corporate behavior, the question becomes what determines media scrutiny. In particular, we are interested in the link between corporate litigation and media coverage.

8.3.2 Corporate Litigation Matters for Media Scrutiny

Before we can apply the law-as-source insights from Chapter 2 to our topic here, we need to answer two questions. First, to what extent do law-as-source benefits stem from the specific channel of litigation, rather than from other legal sources such as disclosure requirements or regulatory enforcement? After all, we are interested in the desirability of shifting to mandatory arbitration, and disclosure or public enforcement will supposedly remain intact even if such a shift occurs. Second, to what extent are the law-as-source benefits of litigation relevant to our particular type, namely, shareholder litigation?

The law-as-source study detailed in Chapter 2 above provides a clear answer to the first question: litigation plays a key role in holding business companies and businesspersons to account, often more important than other types of legal sources. Granted, some media probes rely heavily on “direct” legal sources, such as companies’ public filings with the SEC. But a lot of times, the smoking gun comes rather from “indirect” legal sources, such as law enforcement actions. As Chapter 2 elaborated, the reason is that litigation does not rely on powerful players volunteering damning information about themselves - it forces damning information out of powerful players.

The second question - whether shareholder litigation is as informative as other types of litigation - is harder to answer. The law-as-source study does not answer it directly, if only because Pulitzer prizes are rarely awarded for covering corporate governance issues, and so the content analysis of prizewinning projects does not provide many relevant data points. What the law-as-source study does offer in that regard are more general observations regarding how the media relies on information from litigation when it investigates companies.46 It seems that litigation’s role is actually more pronounced in investigative reporting on corporate behavior, as opposed to investigative reporting on the public sector or the third sector. Virtually every reporters’ tip sheet or course syllabus that deals with how to investigate businesses mentions searching court documents. When I asked investigative reporters why this is so, they suggested a straightforward answer: business journalists rely more heavily on court documents because they have a hard time sourcing stories on business companies in other ways.47 A journalist trying to hold big government to account will have a much easier time getting, for example, tips from the politician’s rivals or relying on FOIA requests or public-records laws.—

The added difficulty of getting information on private businesses seems to increase the demand for getting information from litigation. And, in the words of the Dean of Columbia Journalism School, the supply tends to meet the demand: “[T]here’s hardly a company in this world that is not being sued, and this is where you get a window [into what is going on in the company].”49 A great illustration comes from a study that documented the lack of watchdog journalism by the financial media leading up to the 2008 financial crisis. That study singled out four counterexamples of great investigative pieces.50 When I took a closer look at these projects - the rare pieces that did spotlight the shady Wall Street practices that contributed to the crisis - I learned that all of them relied heavily on court documents.51 Without litigation, media scrutiny of corporate behavior would lose most of its already-diminished effectiveness.

Up to this point, we have broadly discussed litigation against businesses. Yet different types of litigation produce information of different quantities and qualities. Shareholder litigation works differently than, say, product liability litigation. And within shareholder litigation, derivative suits work differently than securities class actions. It is time to delve into specifics and introduce the unique nuances of information production in shareholder litigation.

8.3.3 Front-Loaded Information Production

Shareholder litigation is more front-loaded than other types of litigation. Since the mid-1990s, a series of legislative and judicial reforms have severely curtailed a plaintiffs ability to survive the motion to dismiss stage, let alone reach full-blown discovery.— One could claim that this feature makes it less likely that shareholder litigation would produce valuable information. How can we expect useful information to come out from litigation if only a few complaints reach discovery, and even fewer lead to published judicial opinions? Without the benefit of discovery, how can litigators add information that other market players do not already know?

The answer is straightforward: Reforms that made it tougher to survive earlier stages in litigation did not eliminate the information production, but merely front-loaded it. Plaintiffs in shareholder litigation conduct much more prefiling, prediscovery investigations, and file more fact-rich, detailed initial complaints.— As a result, information about defendants’ behavior is generated at much earlier stages of the litigation process. Shareholder litigation affects the market for reputation even in its infancy.

The front-loaded information production takes different degrees and forms, as a function of the forum and type of claim. With corporate governance matters settled in state courts, the main prediscovery investigatory tool is requesting to inspect the defendant company’s books and records (“section 220 requests,” to use the Delaware jargon).— With securities claims settled in federal courts, section 220 requests are unavailable, and so plaintiffs frequently resort to soliciting inside informants, who confidentially provide damning information about their current or former employers.

  • 8.3.3.1 Corporate Claims in State Courts: Section 220 Requests

In derivative actions, the main event comes before the suit even starts: the demand requirement.55 To survive the demand-requirement stage, plaintiffs practically need to convince the courts that demand is futile because the company’s board is too self-interested to make the right decision.56 To do that, plaintiffs need to meet a heightened pleading standard and show that a majority of the board is implicated in the alleged wrongdoing.57 And they need to clear those hurdles without having the benefits of discovery.58 The solution to this pleading challenge came from the Delaware courts, which started imploring plaintiffs to use all “tools at hand” to generate information pre-suit, particularly their right to inspect the company’s books.59 Plaintiffs heeded the call and started filing section 220 requests more frequently and more broadly.60

Granted, section 220 requests do not generate the same quantity and quality of information as full discovery does.61 But the practice of section 220 requests has developed such that shareholders now use them not just to get technical information such as stock-list materials, but also to extract all internal company documents related to the alleged wrongdoing, such as board minutes, internal memos, and spreadsheets. Forcing companies to volunteer such information can affect reputations, both directly and indirectly. Directly, section 220 requests that produce internal corporate communications give the market a peek behind the corporate curtain, with answers to reputation-relevant questions such as “who knew what when.” Indirectly, section 220 requests allow better pleading and so increase the chances of reaching full discovery, where more relevant information is likely to come out.

To illustrate, we need simply recast the Disney case. There, the initial complaint was dismissed for failure to meet the demand requirement.62 The plaintiffs regrouped and submitted a section 220 request, which generated internal company documents: letters, emails, memoranda, and board minutes.

Armed with the information, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, and this time survived the motion to dismiss, proceeded to discovery and then a full trial.63 Chapter 3 showed how earlier stages in the Disney litigation shaped the frequency and tenor of media coverage of the Disney-Ovitz debacle. Now we can add the important detail of how: it was the prediscovery, section 220 requests that facilitated the reputational effects.

8.3.32 Securities Claims in Federal Courts: Soliciting Whistleblowers

With securities class actions, the main event similarly comes early: the motion to dismiss.64 Out of the many challenges that securities class actions faced over the recent decades, most relevant for our purposes is the combination of heightened pleading standards with a stay on discovery.65 The 1995 Private Securities Litigation Reform Act (PSLRA) requires that plaintiffs plead facts with particularity, showing a strong inference of scienter.66 Such facts about the defendant’ s state of mind must be pled without the benefit of discovery, as the PSLRA also stayed discovery until after the motion to dismiss is decided. As a result, virtually all defendants file motions to dismiss, and plaintiffs have a tough time surviving such motions.67

The combination of heightened pleading standards and stayed discovery seems at first glance like a death knell to information production. Yet here as well, a closer look reveals a different, more dynamic story. Plaintiffs’ lawyers who faced mounting hurdles had to raise their game and conduct more pre-complaint and prediscovery investigations.— They are now said to possess much more information in the motion to dismiss stage, relative to plaintiffs in other cases, and are more likely to plead their allegations in an “awesomely detailed” way.69

Unlike in corporate litigation, section 220 requests were not available to plaintiffs, since the law blocks their usage in securities litigation.70 Plaintiffs had to resort to alternative investigatory tools. Among them, the most common and effective seems to be soliciting whistleblowing: finding current and former employees willing to share damning inside information on the behavior of defendants.71 Indeed, reliance on “information provided by confidential witnesses” has become almost universal in securities class actions.—

These inside informants frequently provide information that outside observers are not privy to, regarding what and how things happened. To illustrate:— In Tsirekidze v. Syntax-Brillian Corp.,— a former top officer provided details on how defendants cooked the books. In Silverman v. Motorola, Inc. ,— eight former employees explained how the company knowingly omitted facts about technological difficulties. In Hubbard v. BankAtlantic Bancorp, Inc.,76 former bank employees fleshed out claims about shady lending practices. As with section 220 requests, the usage of such insider informants affects the market for reputation both indirectly by increasing the chances that complaints reach full discovery, and directly by providing information that can be picked up by the media even at a preliminary stage.

Another element that makes the preliminary stages in securities class actions informative is that the judges themselves are more proactive in generating information. Because the motion to dismiss effectively turned into something akin to a summary judgment, judges examine the pleading with much more rigor. And because courts in securities class actions must investigate all sources of competing inferences of scienter, they often probe even information that was not included in the initial complaint.77

8.4 Can Other Institutions Substitute Litigation's Informational Benefits?

To fully examine the desirability of shifting to mandatory arbitration, we need to consider not just the informational benefits of litigation in its current state, but also the counterfactual: in a world without shareholder litigation, will other enforcement mechanisms step up and provide similar informational benefits to the ones we currently get from litigation? This section considers three such alternatives for information production: public enforcement headed by the SEC, individual arbitration headed by big institutional investors, and section 220 requests or whistleblowing by aggrieved shareholders and employees. The bottom line is the same: none of these institutions would be able to meaningfully substitute the information that would be lost if we switch from litigation to arbitration.

8.4.1 SEC Enforcement

One could argue that in a world where private enforcement happens behind closed doors, public enforcement can still produce enough information to facilitate proper reputational deterrence. The SEC’s enforcement division arguably possesses better tools and incentives than private litigants to produce credible information. The SEC enjoys broader investigative powers compared to the ones private litigants typically enjoy in a post-PSLRA world.78 Private litigants, as the previous chapter detailed, are incentivized to trade away information for money: it is not just that they settle too early and often, but also that they settle too secretly. Almost every settlement comes with some form of a confidentiality clause. By contrast, the SEC can produce press releases that detail their investigations in a fairer way than plaintiffs’-lawyer-worded complaints or media briefs. A shift from litigation to arbitration would therefore only crystalize the waters, as the information environment would be dominated by the better-informed and more credible SEC’s enforcement division.

Yet we have already rebutted the argument that SEC enforcement can fully substitute for the information that comes out of private litigation, in Chapter 4 above. We discussed there why the argument may hold only in a limited sense: in a specific dispute, SEC enforcement may indeed be equally or more informative than private litigation. But from a big-picture perspective, private enforcement produces information in ways and on types of misconduct on which the SEC consistently underproduces information.

A quick recap of the factors we detailed in Chapter 4: First, the SEC faces budgetary constraints, and simply cannot pursue all instances of misconduct. Second, when the SEC prioritizes targets for enforcement, it tends to go after the small fish, less politically connected firms. Third, the SEC maximizes the observable yardsticks of the total amount of fines it collects and the number of enforcement actions it opens, which leads the agency to leave information on the table, in various ways. For example, the SEC lets defendants who are willing to settle early and for nice sums dictate the language and timing of the enforcement action press release. And it targets whole industries for minor, strict-liability-type offenses, which typically do not extract relevant internal documents from the defendant-companies. All these practices, Chapter 4 showed, limit the reputational value of SEC enforcement. It is telling that even SEC commissioners and staffers have long acknowledged that private litigation guards against selective enforcement and inaction on part of the SEC.79 In a world without private litigation, defendants would have stronger incentives to dilute SEC enforcement efforts.— This will dilute not just legal deterrence but also reputational deterrence.

8.4.2 Individual Arbitration

One common criticism of mandatory arbitration provisions with class action waivers goes as follows: these provisions do not merely change the procedure for settling disputes, but rather effectively eliminate disputes, since victims who suffered small damages will not pursue their claims individually.— At first glance, such criticism applies less forcefully in our context, where there are big institutional investors that may have a large enough stake to vigorously pursue individual claims in arbitration. In a world without class actions, institutional investors may even have a legal duty to monitor and follow through on potential misconduct by companies they invest in.82 The question for our purposes is not whether individual arbitration by institutional investors would generate enough compensation, but rather whether it would generate enough information. I tend to answer in the negative, for the following reasons.

For one, fewer instances of corporate misconduct will get flushed out. The whole impetus behind the arbitration-provisions wave is wanting to avoid the need to resolve certain disputes.83 Even in cases where the individual harm is big enough on paper, it is not clear that institutional investors would actually pursue a remedy. Evidence from Europe, where only big institutional investors can bring derivative actions, suggest that in reality most valuable claims are not pursued, partly because it is easier for managers to collude and convince the few players who can bring a claim to not bring it.84 Similarly, in the United States, Professors Bebchuk and Hirst showed that none of the large index funds had been the lead plaintiff in any securities class action over the past ten years.85 They interpret this evidence as suggesting that institutional investors with high-enough stakes prefer, for various reasons, not to vigorously pursue their claims.

Even if one assumes that institutional investors would regularly pursue claims in arbitration, one has to acknowledge that the procedure in arbitration starkly differs from court procedures in ways that limit information production.86 Discovery tends to be much more limited. Depositions are taken only rarely. Plaintiffs’ investigations normally do not extract internal company documents. And so on. In theory, arbitration provisions can be amended to demand a more information-extracting, akin-to-litigation procedure. But that would defeat the purpose behind the wave of arbitration provisions.87 A key purpose in shifting to arbitration, besides eliminating disputes, is limiting the negative publicity from disputes. Confidentiality and privacy are hallmark features in the arbitration procedure. It is therefore hard to imagine companies agreeing to an expansive discovery regime in arbitration.

8.4.3 Section 220 Requests and Whistleblowing

As noted above, filing section 220 requests and finding inside informants are two important investigatory tools in shareholder litigation. One could claim that we do not need litigation to employ these channels of extracting information. These are prefiling investigatory tools, after all, which would supposedly remain available even if we switch to mandatory arbitration.

The argument that standalone section 220 requests (not in conjunction with litigation) can substitute the informational benefits of litigation is easily refutable. It is inconsistent with the logic of incentives and inconsistent with the law. There is a good reason that section 220 requests are usually filed in conjunction with litigation. A shareholder would be willing to go through the costs and trouble of fighting companies for information only when said shareholder (or, more realistically, a plaintiffs law firm) anticipates a potential financial bonanza down the road. Shareholder litigation provides the supercharged economic incentives needed to make the fight worth it.

Even if we assume proper incentives for filing standalone section 220 requests, the law makes such requests irrelevant from an information-production standpoint. The courts have conditioned granting section 220 requests on confidentiality.— If a shareholder wants to enjoy her rights to inspect the books, she must first agree to not diffuse the information she receives. As a result, the only time when section 220 information escapes confidentiality and becomes available is when the requesting shareholder uses the information in conjunction with court filings, such as the initial complaint or as attachments to a motion. In other words, information gleaned from section 220 requests can only affect reputations when it is filed with the court.

The argument that standalone whistleblowing would replace litigation’s informational benefits is harder to refute. There is no law prohibiting the release of information coming from whistleblowers outside litigation, and the incentives problem has supposedly been addressed in the Dodd-Frank Act.— Still, there exist ample indications that without litigation, the whistleblowing would not make an impact. Litigation adds value to the information revealed by amplifying, certifying, and diffusing whistleblowers’ claims. To illustrate, consider Freund v. Lucent Technologies, Inc.,— where plaintiffs submitted a section 220 request for all the materials that were filed in a whistleblowing action (brought by a former senior official who had been fired in retaliation). While the initial whistleblowing did not reverberate publicly, the Lucent litigation made the whistleblower’s information more salient and coverable by the media.91

As the Lucent example illustrates, without litigation, such whistleblowing would be akin to a tree falling in the forest where no one is around - did it really make a sound? With litigation, the whistle gets widely echoed by the press.

8.5 Implications

The policy implication of this chapter’s analysis is straightforward: recognizing the informational role of litigation puts a thumb on the scales against enforcing mandatory arbitration for shareholder claims. If policymakers and courts nevertheless decide to enforce arbitration provisions, we need to design arbitration procedures that allow more information to come out from arbitration.

At the same time, I want to be careful not to overstate my claim. There are two important qualifications. First, any evidence for the informational benefits of litigation is more qualitative in nature. We know that reputation matters, we know that media scrutiny matters, and we know that litigation matters to media scrutiny and reputation. But we have not yet quantified how much exactly it matters: What is the size of these informational benefits of litigation? Second, and relatedly, even if one is convinced that the size of the informational benefits is significant, one still needs to weigh them against the significant costs of litigation.92 After all, our aim is not to maximize production of information, but rather to optimize it. Perhaps the tradeoff that mandatory arbitration offers - less informational benefits with less administrative costs - is worth it from a societal perspective. Against this background, let us go back to what we started this short section with: the two immediate policy implications.

First and most basically, the information-production argument puts a thumb on the scales against mandatory arbitration. A thumb on the scales and not a decisive vote, because we only have suggestive evidence. But what we have is enough to caution against replacing litigation with arbitration without first gaining better evidence and a better understanding of the positive externalities of litigation. Securities markets are fraught with asymmetric information and supercharged incentives to cheat. Reputational deterrence is important to their proper functioning. And litigation seems to be important to the proper functioning of reputational deterrence. The direct costs of litigation are well researched and salient to us, while the costs of reputational under-deterrence are not. If one has to conjecture, I would surmise that the latter far outweigh the former.—

If courts and regulators nevertheless allow companies to adopt arbitration provisions, the second set of policy implications comes in: providing insight into how we would want such arbitration to look. Ideally, in the area of corporate and securities laws we would want arbitration that injects some valuable information into the market. Is there a way to get the cost-saving aspects of arbitration without losing the information-extracting benefits of litigation?

At a minimum, we would want an accessible database of disputes with “explained awards” - arbitrators should include a short summary of who did what to whom, when, and why that is a bad thing. The requirement of explained awards should come from, and be monitored by, the SEC or another regulator. Leaving things to the market will simply not work, as the experience with the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) arbitration forum shows. For over a decade now, FINRA has used a rule that requires explained awards only upon joint requests from both parties.— This opt-in mechanism produced “very, very few” actual explained awards.95 A better design would be to mandate explained awards, or at least set the default differently, so that the parties can opt out of explained awards only upon joint request.

To emphasize: even if arbitration proceeds with a searchable database of disputes and explained awards, it would probably produce much less law-as-source benefits compared to litigation. Most of the impact that law enforcement has on media coverage comes not so much from the outcomes of disputes, but rather from documents that were produced in earlier stages of the process (discovery, depositions, and so on). Arbitration entails much less information-extracting and would surely be less useful to third parties trying to figure out what and how things happened.

8.6 Extensions: Arbitration and Reputation in Other Contexts

We started this chapter by noting that the reputational effects of shifting to mandatory arbitration vary greatly across different contexts. This short section goes beyond the context of shareholder litigation, to demonstrate the various factors in play. We specifically focus on the distant context of employment litigation. Mandatory arbitration of workers’ claims has gone through two major changes in recent years: one legal (the Supreme Court’s Epic decision), and one social/cultural (the #MeToo movement). Section 8.6.1 explains how the Epic decision affects the market for reputation. Section 8.6.2 looks at the other side, namely, how the market for reputation affects firm’s propensity to adopt mandatory arbitration provisions, following the #MeToo movement.

8.6.1 Arbitration of Workplace Claims; Epic Ramifications

In May 2018, the US Supreme Court’s Epic decision enforced arbitration clauses with class waivers in employment contracts.— Large employers were already funneling workplace disputes to arbitration before Epic, and now, when they can effectively eliminate class action, are figured to force such provisions even more aggressively.— Can we apply the argument presented throughout this chapter, in the context of shareholder claims, and similarly make a case against mandatory arbitration in the context of employment claims? Is Epic bad policy?

The answer is yes, but. Yes, I think that Epic would affect reputational deterrence negatively. But I think its effects would be much different than the ones we analyzed in the context of shareholder litigation.

The first difference lies in the “reputation for what” question. While shareholder litigation mostly affects a company’s reputation for quality of governance, employment litigation can also affect a company’s reputation for quality of workplace relations.

Another, much more relevant distinction lies in the “reputation to whom” question. The likelihood that information from litigation would translate into reputational sanctions vary across different stakeholder groups. When shareholder litigation reveals information on the checks and balances inside companies, investors are likely to do something with the information. They have too much skin in the game not to. In employment litigation, by contrast, it is much less clear that information from litigation will actually change how stakeholders treat the company. The relevant stakeholder group here is usually employees. And with employees, it is less likely that litigation will tell them something they did not already know about how the company treats its workers. Unlike investors, who suffer as outsiders from asymmetric information and rational apathy, workers are insiders who are directly affected, and have all the incentives and ability to keep informed about the company’s action. These workers rarely rely on litigation for new information. And they often do not need litigation for mobilization either. In unionized areas, the union can engage management either directly or through media pressure. After all, the Epic decision did not affect workers’ ability to mobilize collectively outside the specific context of class litigation.98 Even in nonunionized areas, workers can arguably mobilize for their causes and enlist the media via non-litigation channels such as social media, as the Market Basket case study illustrates.99

What about a different stakeholder group, namely, consumers? On paper, information from litigation on how firm X mistreats its employees can lead consumers to buy less from firm X going forward. Indeed, many survey-based studies document consumers’ professed willingness to pay more (less) for the products of companies with good (bad) workplace conditions.100 Yet I am skeptical that Epic would actually change consumers’ willingness to pay. For one, as Chapter 5 indicated, evidence shows a gap between consumers’ professions in surveys and their actual buying decisions: in reality, consumers purchase based on product quality and price, and little more. And in many of the cases we can summon from memory where consumers were willing to go the distance and boycott a firm for workplace conditions, it was for violations that are not affected by the Epic decision at all. The classic example here is issues of child labor in third-world countries, which are not the type of wage-and-hour disputes that would have been litigated in US courtrooms regardless of Epic.

Still, I conjecture that Epic would have serious reputational ramifications, if only through a different channel: not necessarily through the reputation-for-workplace dimension, but rather through the reputation-for-governance dimension. In other words, ending public dispute resolution of workplace claims can have a detrimental effect on accountability in other areas beside workplace conditions. This is because information from workplace litigation may help expose shenanigans in other aspects.

A timely illustration comes from the Wells Fargo phony-accounts scandal. An investigative report by the L.A. Times broke the story, showing how pressures from the top of the organization led to shady practices of sucker-punching customers and abusing employees.101 But how was the L.A. Times able to come out with such a story? It turns out that the reporter relied on court documents from wage-and-hours lawsuits filed by disgruntled Wells Fargo employees. A similar, earlier example appears in the Dean Starkman’s book on watchdog business journalism we mentioned earlier: in the 1990s investigative reporters were able to link low-rent operators to Wall Street by trolling employment litigation against financial companies.102 The court documents provided readymade, libel-proof testimonies by former employees, which detailed the lawless culture in the financial companies in question.

Following Epic, such workplace disputes are no longer aired in court. The next time a journalist attempts to expose shenanigans by financial companies, such inside information is more likely to remain out of her reach.

8.6.2 How Reputation Affects Arbitration: the #MeToo Example

After focusing throughout this chapter on how shifting to arbitration can affect the market for reputation, let us switch to the other side: how the market for reputation can affect the shift to arbitration. When a firm adopts a mandatory arbitration provision, it sends a certain signal to the market. Under certain conditions, stakeholders will view the mere adoption of such provision negatively enough to merit boycotting the firm, and the prospect of a reputational sanction will push firms to drop such provisions or not adopt them to begin with.

A classic illustration came throughout 2018-19, in the context of law firms’ employment contracts. Initially, law firms followed the mandatory arbitration trend, forcing their summer interns, associates, and administrative staff to sign contracts with such provisions. And they have gotten away with it, until a social-cultural shift made these provisions more salient and objectionable to their employees. In short, the #MeToo movement happened.

The #MeToo movement increased the saliency of sexual harassment issues. Activist organizations and the media - information intermediaries - started targeting firms who do not do enough to root out sexual harassment. For law firms, specifically, not doing enough about sexual harassment (in our context: trying to force complaints into behind-closed-doors arbitration) started coming with a meaningful reputational risk. The tides turned when a Harvard Law School student group, called the Pipeline Parity Project, started advocating boycotting interviews in firms that force their employees to adhere to such provisions. Fearing reputational damage, one big law firm after another started dropping their mandatory arbitration provisions.103

Can the same dynamics - fear of reputational sanctions pushing firms to avoid forcing arbitration - apply elsewhere? I conjecture that it is less realistic outside this specific law-firm-employment context. For one, the issue here is different: sexual harassment is a much more salient issue (at least at the height of the #MeToo movement) than most other contexts in which consumers are forced to sign arbitration provisions without even caring/knowing about them. Further, the target audience is very different: here the target audience - potential employees - are the relatively sophisticated and aware-to-the-dangers-of-arbitration law students.

It all comes down to solving a collective action problem. For investors in company X, it may be better if company X adopts mandatory arbitration; but for investors as a group, it is better that no company adopts such provision. The increased saliency, low complexity, and levels of engagement by student bodies that we witnessed in the law-firm-employment context usually do not apply in other contexts.

  • 101 E. Scott Reckard, Wells Fargo ‘s Pressure-Cooker Sales Culture Comes at a Cost, l a t i m e s, Dec. 21, 2013.

Conclusion

Five years after the Polinsky and Shavell article that we opened the book with, the movie Spotlight came out. Spotlight won the 2015 Oscar for best film by telling a compelling story about investigative reporters holding the Catholic Church to account over child sex abuse.1 Yet as I was watching the movie, I could not help but see law-and-reputation themes in almost every scene. The Boston Globos Spotlight reporters could not have done it alone. The legal system helped them.2 The Globe reporters spotted the pattern of abuse by looking at numbers of lawsuits filed against individual priests. They revealed the cover-up by getting internal church documents from motions attached to court files. Spotlight is therefore not really a story about investigative journalism holding the powerful to account. It is rather a story about interactions between the media and the courts. Between law and reputation.

The interactions are what produced accountability. Without the legal system generating information in the process of examining individual lawsuits against priests, the reporters would not have had such a powerful story to tell. And without the reporters putting the pieces of the puzzle together, identifying the pattern, packaging it compellingly, and diffusing it widely, the church would not have admitted its mistakes and changed its behavior. The legal system would probably have continued settling and sealing one individual case after another. It took media scrutiny to move the needle.

This book develops a theory of these interactions between law and reputation. It fleshes out how and why such interactions occur, and what outcomes they achieve. Once we are aware of the interactions, we can design legal institutions with an eye to their reputation-affecting role.

It is intuitive to think that decisions and events in the court of law trickle out and affect the court of public opinion, and vice versa. Yet up to this point legal scholars have tended to assume away complementarities between law and reputation, by treating the two systems as independent of each other.3 Law and Reputation challenges the conventional assumption by mapping the various channels through which the law can influence reputational evaluations, and presenting on-the-ground evidence of such influence. Consider the following data point: communication scientists estimate that between a quarter and a third of the content of business media is dedicated to reporting about companies’ interactions with the legal system (regulation, litigation, and corporate governance battles). This data point alone is enough to rid us of the prevalent assumption that law and reputation are independent of each other, and challenge us to start examining how they interact.

The rest of this conclusion offers a brief synthesis of the book’s contributions as they relate to existing literature, before outlining potential future extensions of the reputational framework.

Relation to the Extant Literature

To clarify some of this book’s original contributions, we can juxtapose them with the relevant literature. The Introduction clarified our scope by showing how the questions we are asking differ from the ones that are usually asked in the related literature. This section focuses on how the answers we are providing differ from the ones that others do. The book’s original contributions do not consist in telling us that reputation matters or that the law matters for reputation. We already know that. The contributions consist rather in exploring how the law matters for reputation. Consider the following four examples of gaps in the conventional approach to law and reputation we have sought to narrow.

First, other legal scholars have written about problems with reputational sanctions (usually in the context of making the case for legal intervention).4 But the existing analyses focus almost solely on detection costs, suggesting that market players rarely learn about corporate failures in real time. Law and Reputation shows that another set of costs - enforcement costs - also looms large. Even when market players become aware of a certain failure, they may under or overreact.

Second, Law and Reputation challenges the conventional economic analyses of law and social norms, which treat behavior as either law-complying or norm-following.5 By spotlighting the existing interdependencies, this book illustrates the need to rethink the conventional approach and its policy implications. We cannot use reputation as a justification for deregulation, at least not automatically. If we scale back the background threat of litigation or regulatory investigations, we risk increasing the costs of reputational sanctions. The issue of complementarities between legal and nonlegal systems should therefore move from the periphery to the center of the law and social norms literature.

Relatedly, even when legal scholars recognize the costs of legal and nonlegal systems, they usually do so by taking a horse race approach: identifying areas where informal, nonlegal systems are supposedly better (less costly) than formal, legal systems. I refocus the debate by looking at different systems as providing multiple-layers control or, as it were, a diversified portfolio. Each system of control has its own unique set of costs. And because the systems’ flaws are imperfectly correlated, a combination of several systems cancels out extreme cases of over- or under-sanctioning. The multiple-layers approach is especially suited to the context of complex, atomized markets, where asymmetric information issues abound and any single system alone cannot govern behavior. In other words, one system of control is usually not enough to hold powerful players to account. It takes a village. Recall the Catholic Church’s cover-up of sexual abuse, or DuPont’s toxic emissions. Only a combination of litigation and media scrutiny was able to stop the continuous harmful behavior.

Finally, Law andReputation highlights the importance of the legal process, and in particular the earlier stages of litigation. The rare extant accounts of the reputational role of the law tend to focus on legal outcomes,6 whereas I focus on information disseminated in the process of determining legal outcomes. As Chapters 3 and 4 show, for example, two SEC enforcement actions or Delaware trials with identical legal outcomes may generate completely different reputational outcomes.7 To be sure, I do not claim that my account precludes others. The law produces information in various ways and to various effects. The key is to identify the subsets of cases that are relevant for each type of effect. In corporate law litigation, for example, the filing of a lawsuit or the rendering of a judicial opinion probably generates less reputational impact than the information coming out during the process (such as in the discovery stage or in prediscovery requests to inspect the books). Shifting our attention from the outcomes of legal disputes to the process comes with important implications. If we want to improve information production, we need to rethink seemingly nonsubstantive doctrines such as pleading standards, plaintiffs’ rights to demand inside information in discovery, openness of court proceedings, and the desirability of arbitration clauses.

Potential Extensions

The interactions between two complex systems such as law and reputation are a vast topic. Accordingly, considerations of brevity and scope have compelled me to leave important angles out of this book, in the hope that future work can address them. Consider the following four specific avenues: engaging in quantitative empirical work to test some of the hypotheses developed here in qualitative methods, elaborating on the hypotheses’ normative implications, and broadening the scope of analysis to incorporate other legal fields and other legal systems.

Empirical Extensions

The insights developed here rely on mixed methods, mostly qualitative in nature, such as interviews, case studies, and content analysis. As the Introduction clarified, such methodology makes sense when the aim is to generate hypotheses and indicate the plausibility of the hypotheses - a required step when approaching an undeveloped field. Now that we have chartered the territory of law and reputation, we need to take the next step of building on some of the exploratory work done here and designing more quantitative tests of the hypotheses.8 As a caveat, I do not claim that my qualitative empirical work here has produced conclusive proofs of my theory or generated external validity in the sense in which the term is used in quantitative studies. What my work has produced, I hope, is a rich theory, one that is valid in the modest sense of prima facie credibility, and that can pave the way for subsequent quantitative probes.

Normative Extensions

Reputational forces do not always promote overall welfare. At first glance, this book can be read as too much of a paean to how reputation incentivizes companies to engage in nice behaviors or avoid bad behaviors. A more accurate statement of my claim is that reputational forces incentivize companies to appear moral and competent. In the real world, given asymmetric information, corporate insiders sometimes take actions that appear good but are actually detrimental to their agents. The book alludes to such “bad reputation effects,”9 for example, in the context of how regulators can co-opt court-induced reputational pressures by responding too aggressively or symbolically. But there is room for more detailed analysis.

Another avenue for future research on the normative aspects of law and reputation is the phenomenon of reputational spillovers. We have discussed how legal enforcement actions affect the reputation of defendant companies and businesspeople. But in reality enforcement actions against one company may affect the defendant’s peers as well. Outside stakeholders often do not completely differentiate between peer companies’ reputations. The revelation of bad news about one company may cause stakeholders to lose trust in the whole industry or market.10 Such dynamics of spillovers and cascades open the door to interesting normative implications. Consider for example an extension of the “make it look like a struggle” idea from Chapter 3. Counterintuitively, when Delaware courts and the SEC manage to appear tougher than they truly are on corporate America, they may actually promote overall welfare under certain conditions, by containing reputational spillovers. If the public and politicians overreact to isolated corporate failures, then courts that follow a make-it-look-like-a-struggle strategy may help to restore trust in markets without unnecessarily punishing good companies or committing to overregulation.

Other Legal Fields

We can also broaden the scope of the law-and-reputation argument by applying it to legal fields we did not cover here. The law generates reputation-shaping effects to various degrees even in seemingly remote areas. The book focused on corporate and securities laws, while also discussing product liability, administrative law, and even labor law applications. Elsewhere I touched on applications to public international law.11 Future research can further extend the applications to classic private law. Consider two examples that I am currently working on.

In tort law, the reputational perspective can shed light on the long-standing debate of negligence versus strict liability.12 Conventional economic analysis treats the prevalence of negligence regimes as a puzzle: on paper, a strict-liability rule would be preferable as it leads to optimal activity levels. Such an analysis assumes that liability rules affect behavior only directly, through imposing legal sanctions. Yet, as this book showed, liability rules can also affect behavior through producing information. Take medical malpractice, for example. Litigation under a negligence regime produces reputation-relevant information, such as whether the facility was properly maintained, or whether the doctor used the most up-to-date methods. It gives outside observers information that they can use to evaluate whether the problem is indicative of future behavior or not. Do I want to be hospitalized in this facility or operated on by this doctor or not? Litigation under strict liability, by contrast, does not focus on how things happened but only on what happened. It produces much less reputation-relevant information. In that way, negligence regimes affect the activity levels too, albeit indirectly: by producing information, they dictate how many future patients will go to the doctor in question.

In contract law, the reputational perspective spotlights a counterintuitive problem in the shift to personalized contracts.— Sellers increasingly rely on big data and predictive analytics to identify potential “nudnik” consumers: those consumers who are more likely to voice concerns publicly, such as posting detailed negative reviews online, enlisting the help of the media, or complaining to the regulator. This small group of consumers is an engine of market discipline. They are the ones generating most of the reputation-relevant information on sellers. While most of us do not even notice when we are overcharged by $4 on a takeout order, these nudniks do, and their activism holds sellers accountable. Yet if sellers can now identify who is a nudnik before that consumer even steps into their store, they can effectively silence the nudnik or avoid selling to her altogether. In other words, an unexplored dark side of big data is that it can be used to reduce the expected reputational sanction for overcharging, mistreating a customer, or selling a defective product. This technology is good for companies. It may actually be good for the targeted consumer herself, because sellers often offer her preferential treatment. Yet it is bad for the market overall. Legal intervention may be needed to protect the market for seller reputation.

Other Legal Systems

Another fertile ground for future research is the comparative aspects of law and reputation. The examples used throughout the book come mainly from US law. Some of the reason for this is practical: the United States is where I studied, taught, and consulted on law and reputation when I was formulating my ideas. But there is also substantive reason to focus on the United States: the American legal system is more geared toward information production than any other legal system in the world. For one, discovery is the most far-reaching.14 And plaintiffs and their lawyers enjoy high-powered economic incentives to extract information: the bounty is higher.

Yet, while the reputational effects of the law may be strongest in the United States, logic and anecdotal examples suggest that they apply to some extent in other systems as well. When Oxford’s John Armour was assigned to comment on my law-as-source project, he did his own digging, and found that legal sources were indeed behind over half of the top investigative projects in the United Kingdom as well. And in a current project where I examine Israel’s move to a Delaware-style business court, the early findings are in line with what we saw in Chapter 3: the biggest change from moving to Delaware-style adjudication is not in substantive law but rather in the more intensive media coverage and the reputational effects of the legal disputes. The new business court shapes behavior mainly indirectly. In other, non-common-law systems, the reputational effects seem to be more limited. In Germany, for example, the names of the disputants are confidential. This takes away the ability of investigative reporters to cull court documents to find patterns of misbehavior, as elaborated in Chapter 7.

Along these lines, a promising venue for comparative inquiry is to apply the reputational framework to the “what matters” debate that has been dominating the law and finance literature since the 1990s. The extant literature has been trying to locate the determinants of strong corporate governance and capital markets, searching for systematic differences in either legal, market, or social controls across countries. Yet one important difference has been left relatively understudied: the differences in interactions between systems of control. The reputational perspective suggests the possibility that the variation in outcomes across countries is driven not just by how each system functions in isolation, but also by how the systems affect each other. Systems of control can facilitate each other in one country while crowding each other out in another country. Specifically, when measuring the effectiveness of legal enforcement, we should try to capture the indirect effects too, by asking whether the legal system facilitates better nonlegal controls.15

My initial conjecture is that countries with adjudication systems that provide quality information to the market can afford to rely more heavily on market solutions. This is because litigation (or regulatory investigations) that provide information in a timely, accessible, and accurate manner facilitates better reputational control. Such a perspective suggests a new explanation for the relative strength of US corporate governance. Perhaps the genius of American corporate law comes not from well-designed and strictly enforced substantive rules, but rather from civil procedure rules that are geared toward information production.16

***

This book centers around one overarching point: the law shapes behavior not just through imposing sanctions, but also through producing information. In the course of fleshing out this point and examining the interactions between law and reputation, the book contributes to various debates that have been at the center of academics’ and practitioners’ attention, such as the desirability of heightened pleading standards or mandatory arbitration clauses.

Delving into the interconnections between law and reputation also sheds new light on age-old policy debates. Two binary camps have been dominating the debate over legal intervention: one camp advocates “leaving things to the market” while the other calls for “ramping up legal sanctioning.” Yet those who oppose legal intervention fail to recognize the importance of the legal system for the functioning of market discipline. And those who advocate for more legal sanctions fail to recognize the ability of the legal system to shape behavior indirectly, without interfering with business decisions. Sometimes the most effective and realistic way to promote deterrence is not to increase legal sanctions, but to increase the quantity and quality of information production.

Appendix A Interviews

To capture the fuzzy dynamics of how law affects reputation, I conducted in-depth open conversational interviews with veteran journalists, reputation consultants, and litigators. In this type of interview, the researcher introduces a topic in broad strokes, the interviewee talks freely about the interviewee’s experience and insights into the topic, and the researcher further probes specific experiences with follow-up questions.

The interviews played an especially important part in Chapter 2's insights on how the law affects investigative reporting. As a way to introduce the topic, I started all interviews with the same research question, namely, “What role do you think that legal sources play in investigative reporting?” I also included in almost every interview some questions about variation across issues and over time, such as “Is it harder as a reporter to hold big government to account than it is to hold big business to account, or vice versa?,” and “How have the legal sourcing dynamics you just described changed over time?” When interviewing Pulitzer winners, I asked them specifically, “What role did legal sources play in your [winning project]?” and we went into detail and clarifications.

The interviewing is of course subject to biases. Your interviewees may tell you what they think you want to hear or distort their responses to boost their image. Two factors alleviate such concerns here. First, as Chapter 2 noted, the insights presented here are based on triangulation: not just what journalists say about legal sources when they talk with me, but also what they say when they talk with themselves (tip sheets/syllabi), and what they actually do (content analysis). Second, overstating the role of legal sources is actually the opposite of what a journalist who wishes to boost her image would do. If a journalist tilts her answers in a self-serving way, why would she suggest that she merely piggybacked existing public documents? She is better off claiming more credit to her hard-working, developing-ears-on-the-streets efforts.

In compiling the sample of interviewees, I focused on two groups. For the first batch of interviews I approached journalists who served or are currently serving in big-picture-type positions: directors and founders of investigative reporting centers, heads of academic units of investigative reporting, veteran editors, and so on. I made a concerted effort to approach reporters with varied experiences - as reporters and editors, in broadcast and print media, covering the financial market beat and covering criminal cases, and so forth. The second batch of interviewees were winners of the Pulitzer Prize for Investigative Reporting in 1995-2015. In both groups, roughly two-thirds of the journalists I approached agreed to interview for this project.

Table A1 details the interviews of the law-as-source study. Unless noted otherwise, I conducted the interviews by phone. I then list some of the most helpful and influential interviews I have had in the earlier stages of formulating this book’s thesis.
